764401_14_ITEM5_P3_S0	On November 18, 2008, our Board of Directors approved a share repurchase authorization to buy back up to $25.0 million of our outstanding common stock.
764401_14_ITEM5_P4_S0	Repurchases may be made from time to time in the open market or in privately negotiated transactions subject to market conditions, applicable legal requirements and other factors.
764401_14_ITEM5_P4_S1	We are not obligated to acquire any particular amount of common stock and may commence or suspend the program at any time at our discretion without prior notice.
764401_14_ITEM5_P4_S2	The share repurchase authorization continues in effect until terminated by the Board of Directors.
764401_14_ITEM5_P4_S3	As of September 27, 2014, there was $24.8 million remaining available for future share repurchases under this authorization.
764401_14_ITEM5_P4_S4	We did not repurchase any shares of our common stock during fiscal 2014 and 2013.
764401_14_ITEM5_P5_S0	On April 21, 2009, the Board of Directors adopted Amendment No. 1 to Rights Agreement, effective April 25, 2009, amending the Rights Agreement dated as of April 27, 1999 between us and American Stock Transfer Trust Company, LLC, successor to First Union National Bank.
764401_14_ITEM5_P5_S1	No. 1 and the Rights Agreement are hereinafter collectively referred to as the Rights Agreement.
764401_14_ITEM5_P5_S2	In connection with adopting the Rights Agreement, on April 26, 1999, the Board of Directors declared a dividend distribution of one right per share of our outstanding common stock as of May 17, 1999.
764401_14_ITEM5_P5_S3	The Rights Agreement also provides that one right will attach to each share of our common stock issued after May 17, 1999.
764401_14_ITEM5_P5_S4	Each right entitles the registered holder to purchase from us on certain dates described in the Rights Agreement one two-hundredths of a share (a Unit ) of our Series A Junior Participating Preferred Stock at a purchase price of $46 per Unit, subject to adjustment as described in the Rights Agreement.
764401_14_ITEM5_P5_S5	For more information regarding our Rights Agreement, see Note 18 to the consolidated financial statements.
764401_14_ITEM7_P0_S0	The matters discussed in this section include forward-looking statements that are subject to numerous risks.
764401_14_ITEM7_P0_S1	You should carefully read the Cautionary Note Regarding Forward-Looking Statements and Risk Factors in this Form 10-K.
764401_14_ITEM7_P1_S0	Our operations are entirely focused on the manufacture and marketing of concrete reinforcing products for the concrete construction industry.
764401_14_ITEM7_P1_S1	Our business strategy is focused on: (1) achieving leadership positions in our markets; (2) operating as the lowest cost producer; and (3) pursuing growth opportunities within our core businesses that further our penetration of the markets we currently serve or expand our geographic footprint.
764401_14_ITEM7_P2_S0	On August 15, 2014, we, through our wholly-owned subsidiary, IWP, purchased substantially all of the assets associated with the PC strand business of ASW for an adjusted purchase price of $33.9 million, subject to certain additional post-closing adjustments.
764401_14_ITEM7_P3_S0	ASW manufactured PC strand at facilities located in Houston, Texas and Newnan, Georgia (see Note 4 to the consolidated financial statements).
764401_14_ITEM7_P3_S1	We acquired, among other assets, the accounts receivable and inventories related to ASW s PC strand business, the production equipment at its facility in Houston, Texas and its production equipment and facility in Newnan, Georgia.
764401_14_ITEM7_P3_S2	We also entered into an agreement pursuant to which we lease the Houston facility from ASW with an option to purchase it in the future.
764401_14_ITEM7_P4_S0	Our financial statements have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States ( GAAP ).
764401_14_ITEM7_P4_S1	Our discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations are based on these financial statements.
764401_14_ITEM7_P4_S2	The preparation of our financial statements requires the application of these accounting principles in addition to certain estimates and judgments based on current available information, actuarial estimates, historical results and other assumptions believed to be reasonable.
764401_14_ITEM7_P4_S3	Actual results could differ from these estimates.
764401_14_ITEM7_P5_S0	Following is a discussion of our most critical accounting policies, which are those that are both important to the depiction of our financial condition and results of operations and that require judgments, assumptions and estimates.
764401_14_ITEM7_P6_S0	We recognize revenue from product sales when products are shipped and risk of loss and title has passed to the customer.
764401_14_ITEM7_P6_S1	Sales taxes collected from customers are recorded on a net basis and as such, are excluded from revenue.
764401_14_ITEM7_P7_S0	Financial instruments that subject us to concentrations of credit risk consist principally of cash and cash equivalents and trade accounts receivable.
764401_14_ITEM7_P7_S1	Our cash is concentrated primarily at one financial institution, which at times exceeds federally insured limits.
764401_14_ITEM7_P7_S2	We are exposed to credit risk in the event of default by institutions in which our cash and cash equivalents are held and by customers to the extent of the amounts recorded on the balance sheet.
764401_14_ITEM7_P8_S0	We invest excess cash primarily in money market funds, which are highly liquid securities that bear minimal risk.
764401_14_ITEM7_P9_S0	Most of our accounts receivable are due from customers that are located in the U.S. and we generally require no collateral depending upon the creditworthiness of the account.
764401_14_ITEM7_P9_S1	We provide an allowance for doubtful accounts based upon our assessment of the credit risk of specific customers, historical trends and other information.
764401_14_ITEM7_P10_S0	There is no disproportionate concentration of credit risk.
764401_14_ITEM7_P11_S0	We maintain allowances for doubtful accounts for estimated losses resulting from the potential inability of our customers to make required payments on outstanding balances owed to us.
764401_14_ITEM7_P11_S1	Significant management judgments and estimates are used in establishing the allowances.
764401_14_ITEM7_P11_S2	These judgments and estimates consider such factors as customers financial position, cash flows and payment history as well as current and expected business conditions.
764401_14_ITEM7_P11_S3	It is reasonably likely that actual collections will differ from our estimates, which may result in increases or decreases in the allowances.
764401_14_ITEM7_P11_S4	Adjustments to the allowances may also be required if there are significant changes in the financial condition of our customers.
764401_14_ITEM7_P12_S0	We periodically evaluate the carrying value of our inventory.
764401_14_ITEM7_P12_S1	This evaluation includes assessing the adequacy of allowances to cover losses in the normal course of operations, providing for excess and obsolete inventory, and ensuring that inventory is valued at the lower of cost or estimated net realizable value.
764401_14_ITEM7_P12_S2	Our evaluation considers such factors as the cost of inventory, future demand, our historical experience and market conditions.
764401_14_ITEM7_P12_S3	In assessing the realization of inventory values, we are required to make judgments and estimates regarding future market conditions.
764401_14_ITEM7_P12_S4	Because of the subjective nature of these judgments and estimates, it is reasonably likely that actual outcomes will differ from our estimates.
764401_14_ITEM7_P12_S5	Adjustments to these reserves may be required if actual market conditions for our products are substantially different than the assumptions underlying our estimates.
764401_14_ITEM7_P13_S0	We review long-lived assets, which consist principally of property, plant and equipment and finite-lived intangibles, for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value of the asset may not be fully recoverable.
764401_14_ITEM7_P13_S1	Recoverability of long-lived assets to be held and used is measured based on the future net undiscounted cash flows expected to be generated by the related asset or asset group.
764401_14_ITEM7_P13_S2	If it is determined that an impairment loss has been incurred, the impairment loss is recognized in the period in which it is incurred and is calculated based on the difference between the carrying value and the present value of estimated future net cash flows or comparable market values.
764401_14_ITEM7_P14_S0	Assets to be disposed of by sale are recorded at the lower of carrying value or fair value less selling cost when we have committed to a disposal plan, and are reported separately as assets held for sale on our balance sheet.
764401_14_ITEM7_P15_S0	Unforeseen events and changes in circumstances and market conditions could negatively affect the value of assets and result in an impairment charge.
764401_14_ITEM7_P16_S0	Goodwill is tested annually for impairment and whenever events or circumstances change that would make it more likely than not that an impairment may have occurred.
764401_14_ITEM7_P16_S1	We perform our annual impairment analysis as of the first day of the fourth quarter each fiscal year, which involves comparing the current estimated fair value of each reporting unit to its recorded value, including goodwill.
764401_14_ITEM7_P17_S0	We will perform a qualitative assessment to determine whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of the reporting unit is less than its carrying amount.
764401_14_ITEM7_P17_S1	It may be necessary to perform a quantitative analysis where a discounted cash flow model is used to determine the current estimated fair value of the reporting unit.
764401_14_ITEM7_P17_S2	Key assumptions used to determine the fair value of the reporting unit as part of our annual testing (and any required interim testing) include: (a) expected cash flow for the five-year period following the testing date; (b) an estimated terminal value using a terminal year growth rate based on the growth prospects of the reporting unit; (c) a discount rate based on our estimated after-tax weighted average cost of capital; and (d) a probability-weighted scenario approach by which varying cash flows are assigned to alternative scenarios based on their likelihood of occurrence.
764401_14_ITEM7_P17_S3	In developing these assumptions, we consider historical and anticipated future results, general economic and market conditions, the impact of planned business and operational strategies and all available information at the time the fair value of the reporting unit is estimated.
764401_14_ITEM7_P18_S0	We will monitor operating results within the reporting unit throughout the upcoming year to determine if events or changes in circumstances warrant any interim impairment testing.
764401_14_ITEM7_P18_S1	Otherwise, the reporting unit will be subject to the required annual impairment test during our fourth quarter of fiscal 2015.
764401_14_ITEM7_P18_S2	Changes in the judgments and estimates underlying our analysis of goodwill for possible impairment, including the expected future operating cash flows and discount rate, could reduce the estimated fair value of our reporting unit in the future and result in an impairment of goodwill.
764401_14_ITEM7_P19_S0	We are self-insured for certain losses relating to medical and workers compensation claims.
764401_14_ITEM7_P19_S1	Self-insurance claims filed and claims incurred but not reported are accrued based upon our estimates of the discounted ultimate cost for uninsured claims incurred using actuarial assumptions followed by the insurance industry and historical experience.
764401_14_ITEM7_P19_S2	These estimates are subject to a high degree of variability based upon future inflation rates, litigation trends, changes in benefit levels and claim settlement patterns.
764401_14_ITEM7_P19_S3	Because of uncertainties related to these factors as well as the possibility of changes in the underlying facts and circumstances, future adjustments to these reserves may be required.
764401_14_ITEM7_P20_S0	From time to time, we may be involved in claims, lawsuits and other proceedings.
764401_14_ITEM7_P20_S1	The eventual outcome of such matters and the potential losses that we may ultimately incur are subject to a high degree of uncertainty.
764401_14_ITEM7_P21_S0	We record expenses for litigation when it is probable that a liability has been incurred and the amount of the loss can be reasonably estimated.
764401_14_ITEM7_P21_S1	We estimate the probability of such losses based on the advice of legal counsel, the outcome of similar litigation, the status of the lawsuits and other factors.
764401_14_ITEM7_P21_S2	Due to the numerous factors that enter into these judgments and assumptions, it is reasonably likely that actual outcomes will differ from our estimates.
764401_14_ITEM7_P21_S3	We monitor our potential exposure to these contingencies on a regular basis and may adjust our estimates as additional information becomes available or as there are significant developments.
764401_14_ITEM7_P22_S0	Topic 718, Compensation - Stock Compensation.
764401_14_ITEM7_P22_S1	Under these provisions, compensation cost is recognized based on the fair value of equity awards on the date of grant.
764401_14_ITEM7_P22_S2	The compensation cost is then amortized on a straight-line basis over the vesting period.
764401_14_ITEM7_P23_S0	We use the Monte Carlo valuation model to determine the fair value of stock options at the date of grant, which requires us to make assumptions such as expected term, volatility and forfeiture rates to determine the stock options fair value.
764401_14_ITEM7_P23_S1	These assumptions are based on historical information and judgment regarding market factors and trends.
764401_14_ITEM7_P23_S2	If actual results differ from our assumptions and judgments used in estimating these factors, future adjustments to these estimates may be required.
764401_14_ITEM7_P24_S0	Assumptions for employee benefit plans .
764401_14_ITEM7_P24_S1	We account for our defined employee benefit plans, the Insteel Wire Products Company Retirement Income Plan for Hourly Employees, Wilmington, Delaware (the Delaware Plan ) and the supplemental employee retirement plans (each, a SERP ) in accordance with FASB ASC Topic 715, Compensation - Retirement Benefits.
764401_14_ITEM7_P25_S0	Under the provisions of ASC Topic 715, we recognize net periodic pension costs and value pension assets or liabilities based on certain actuarial assumptions, principally the assumed discount rate and the assumed long-term rate of return on plan assets.
764401_14_ITEM7_P26_S0	The discount rates we utilize for determining net periodic pension costs and the related benefit obligations for our plans are based, in part, on current interest rates earned on long-term bonds that receive one of the two highest ratings assigned by recognized rating agencies.
764401_14_ITEM7_P26_S1	Our discount rate assumptions are adjusted as of each valuation date to reflect current interest rates on such long-term bonds.
764401_14_ITEM7_P26_S2	The discount rates are used to determine the actuarial present value of the benefit obligations as of the valuation date as well as the interest component of the net periodic pension cost for the following year.
764401_14_ITEM7_P26_S3	The discount rate for the Delaware Plan and SERPs was 4.25%, 4.75% and 4.00% for 2014, 2013 and 2012, respectively.
764401_14_ITEM7_P27_S0	The assumed long-term rate of return on plan assets for the Delaware Plan represents the estimated average rate of return expected to be earned on the funds invested or to be invested in the plan s assets to fund the benefit payments inherent in the projected benefit obligations.
764401_14_ITEM7_P27_S1	Unlike the discount rate, which is adjusted each year based on changes in current long-term interest rates, the assumed long-term rate of return on plan assets will not necessarily change based upon the actual short-term performance of the plan assets in any given year.
764401_14_ITEM7_P27_S2	The amount of net periodic pension cost or benefit that is recorded each year is based on the assumed long-term rate of return on plan assets for the plan and the actual fair value of the plan assets as of the beginning of the year.
764401_14_ITEM7_P27_S3	We regularly review our actual asset allocation and, when appropriate, rebalance the investments in the plan to more accurately reflect the targeted allocation.
764401_14_ITEM7_P28_S0	For 2014, 2013 and 2012, the assumed long-term rate of return utilized for the Delaware Plan assets was 8%.
764401_14_ITEM7_P28_S1	We currently expect to use the same assumed rate for the long-term return on plan assets in 2015.
764401_14_ITEM7_P28_S2	In determining the appropriateness of this assumption, we considered the historical rate of return on the plan assets, the current and projected asset mix, our investment objectives and information provided by our third-party investment advisors.
764401_14_ITEM7_P29_S0	The projected benefit obligations and net periodic pension cost for the SERPs are based in part on expected increases in future compensation levels.
764401_14_ITEM7_P29_S1	Our assumption for the expected increase in future compensation levels is based upon our average historical experience and our intentions regarding future compensation increases, which generally approximates average long-term inflation rates.
764401_14_ITEM7_P30_S0	Assumed discount rates and rates of return on plan assets are reevaluated annually.
764401_14_ITEM7_P30_S1	Changes in these assumptions can result in the recognition of materially different pension costs over different periods and materially different asset and liability amounts in our consolidated financial statements.
764401_14_ITEM7_P31_S0	A reduction in the assumed discount rate generally results in an actuarial loss, as the actuarially-determined present value of estimated future benefit payments will increase.
764401_14_ITEM7_P31_S1	Conversely, an increase in the assumed discount rate generally results in an actuarial gain.
764401_14_ITEM7_P31_S2	In addition, an actual return on plan assets for a given year that is greater than the assumed return on plan assets results in an actuarial gain, while an actual return on plan assets that is less than the assumed return results in an actuarial loss.
764401_14_ITEM7_P31_S3	Other actual outcomes that differ from previous assumptions, such as individuals living longer or shorter lives than assumed in the mortality tables that are also used to determine the actuarially-determined present value of estimated future benefit payments, changes in such mortality tables themselves or plan amendments will also result in actuarial losses or gains.
764401_14_ITEM7_P31_S4	Under GAAP, actuarial gains and losses are deferred and amortized into income over future periods based upon the expected average remaining service life of the active plan participants (for plans for which benefits are still being earned by active employees) or the average remaining life expectancy of the inactive participants (for plans for which benefits are not still being earned by active employees).
764401_14_ITEM7_P31_S5	However, any actuarial gains generated in future periods reduce the negative amortization effect of any cumulative unamortized actuarial losses, while any actuarial losses generated in future periods reduce the favorable amortization effect of any cumulative unamortized actuarial gains.
764401_14_ITEM7_P32_S0	The amounts recognized as net periodic pension cost and as pension assets or liabilities are based upon the actuarial assumptions discussed above.
764401_14_ITEM7_P33_S0	We believe that all of the actuarial assumptions used for determining the net periodic pension costs and pension assets or liabilities related to the Delaware Plan are reasonable and appropriate.
764401_14_ITEM7_P34_S0	The funding requirements for the Delaware Plan are based upon applicable regulations, and will generally differ from the amount of pension cost recognized under ASC Topic 715 for financial reporting purposes.
764401_14_ITEM7_P34_S1	During 2014, 2013 and 2012, we made contributions totaling $240,000, $307,000 and $206,000, respectively, to the Delaware Plan.
764401_14_ITEM7_P35_S0	We currently expect net periodic pension (benefit) cost for 2015 to be ($8,000) for the Delaware Plan and $644,000 for the SERPs.
764401_14_ITEM7_P35_S1	Cash contributions to the plans during 2015 are expected to be $261,000 for the Delaware Plan and $290,000 for the SERPs.
764401_14_ITEM7_P36_S0	A 0.25% decrease in the assumed discount rate for the Delaware Plan would have increased our projected and accumulated benefit obligations as of September 27, 2014 by approximately $85,000 and have no impact on our expected net periodic pension benefit for 2015.
764401_14_ITEM7_P36_S1	A 0.25% decrease in the assumed discount rate for our SERPs would have increased our projected and accumulated benefit obligations as of September 27, 2014 by approximately $241,000 and $190,000, respectively, and our expected net periodic pension cost for 2015 by approximately $21,000.
764401_14_ITEM7_P37_S0	A 0.25% decrease in the assumed long-term rate of return on plan assets for the Delaware Plan would have reduced our expected net periodic pension benefit for 2015 by approximately $6,000.
764401_14_ITEM7_P38_S0	In February 2013, the FASB issued ASU No. 2013-02 Reporting of Amounts Reclassified Out of Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income.
764401_14_ITEM7_P38_S1	ASU No. 2013-02 requires an entity to disaggregate the total change of each component of other comprehensive income either on the face of the income statement or as a separate disclosure in the notes.
764401_14_ITEM7_P38_S2	We adopted ASU No. 2013-02 in the first quarter of fiscal 2014.
764401_14_ITEM7_P38_S3	The adoption of this update did not have a material effect on our consolidated financial statements.
764401_14_ITEM7_P39_S0	In May 2014, the FASB issued ASU No. 2014-09 Revenue from Contracts with Customers, which will supersede nearly all existing revenue recognition guidance under GAAP.
764401_14_ITEM7_P39_S1	ASU No. 2014-09 provides that an entity recognize revenue when it transfers promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services.
764401_14_ITEM7_P39_S2	This update also requires additional disclosure about the nature, amount, timing and uncertainty of revenue and cash flows arising from customer contracts, including significant judgments and changes in judgments, and assets recognized from costs incurred to obtain or fulfill a contract.
764401_14_ITEM7_P39_S3	ASU No. 2014-09 allows for either full retrospective or modified retrospective adoption and will become effective for us in the first quarter of fiscal 2018.
764401_14_ITEM7_P39_S4	We are evaluating the alternative transition methods and the potential effects of the adoption of this update on our consolidated financial statements.
764401_14_ITEM7_P40_S0	Net sales increased 12.4% to $409.0 million in 2014 from $363.9 million in 2013.
764401_14_ITEM7_P40_S1	Shipments for the year increased 12.8% while average selling prices decreased 0.3% from the prior year levels.
764401_14_ITEM7_P40_S2	The increase in shipments was primarily due to improved market conditions and increased demand for our products relative to the prior year as well as the addition of the ASW facilities for a portion of our fourth quarter.
764401_14_ITEM7_P40_S3	Sales for both years reflect depressed volumes on an absolute basis relative to the prerecession levels in our construction end-markets.
764401_14_ITEM7_P41_S0	Gross profit increased 24.3% to $48.8 million, or 11.9% of net sales, in 2014 from $39.2 million, or 10.8% of net sales, in 2013.
764401_14_ITEM7_P41_S1	The year-over-year increase was primarily due to wider spreads between average selling prices and raw material costs ($6.8 million) and higher shipments ($5.4 million), partially offset by higher unit conversion costs ($1.2 million).
764401_14_ITEM7_P41_S2	The increase in spreads was driven by lower raw material costs ($8.5 million) partially offset by lower average selling prices ($1.4 million) and higher freight expense ($0.3 million).
764401_14_ITEM7_P41_S3	Gross profit for both years was unfavorably impacted by depressed shipment volumes and elevated unit conversion costs largely driven by reduced operating schedules.
764401_14_ITEM7_P42_S0	Selling, general and administrative expense ( SG A expense ) increased 13.0% to $23.4 million, or 5.7% of net sales, in 2014 from $20.7 million, or 5.7% of net sales, in 2013 primarily due to increases in compensation ($1.7 million), employee benefits ($0.3 million), amortization of intangible assets ($0.3 million) and bad debt expense ($0.2 million).
764401_14_ITEM7_P42_S1	The increase in compensation expense was primarily driven by higher incentive plan expense due to our improved financial results in the current year.
764401_14_ITEM7_P42_S2	The increase in employee benefits expense was primarily due to higher employee health insurance costs during 2014.
764401_14_ITEM7_P42_S3	The higher amortization expense is related to the additional intangible assets that were acquired in connection with the ASW Acquisition.
764401_14_ITEM7_P42_S4	The increase in bad debt expense was due to an adjustment to the allowance for doubtful accounts driven by the increase in sales and accounts receivable.
764401_14_ITEM7_P43_S0	Net restructuring charges of $1.2 million were incurred in 2014 for employee separation costs associated with staffing reductions that were implemented in connection with the ASW Acquisition.
764401_14_ITEM7_P44_S0	Acquisition costs of $0.6 million were incurred in 2014 for legal, accounting and other professional fees related to the ASW Acquisition.
764401_14_ITEM7_P44_S1	The accounting requirements for business combinations require the expensing of acquisition costs in the period in which they are incurred.
764401_14_ITEM7_P45_S0	Other income for 2014 was $1.9 million compared to $0.3 million of other expense in 2013.
764401_14_ITEM7_P45_S1	The other income for the current year was primarily due to the net gain from insurance proceeds attributable to the replacement of property and equipment damaged in the fire at our Gallatin, Tennessee PC strand manufacturing facility.
764401_14_ITEM7_P45_S2	Other expense for 2013 was primarily due to a net loss on the disposal of equipment.
764401_14_ITEM7_P46_S0	Interest expense increased 7.2% to $252,000 in 2014 from $235,000 in 2013 primarily due to higher average debt outstanding during 2014.
764401_14_ITEM7_P47_S0	Our effective income tax rate was 34.0% in 2014 compared with 34.8% in 2013 due to changes in permanent book versus tax differences.
764401_14_ITEM7_P48_S0	Net earnings increased to $16.6 million ($0.89 per diluted share) in 2014 from $11.7 million ($0.64 per diluted share) in 2013 primarily due to the increase in gross profit partially offset by higher SG A expense together with the acquisition costs and restructuring charges associated with the ASW Acquisition.
764401_14_ITEM7_P49_S0	Net sales for 2013 were relatively flat at $363.9 million compared with $363.3 million in 2012.
764401_14_ITEM7_P49_S1	Shipments for 2013 increased 4.6% while average selling prices decreased 4.3% from the prior year levels.
764401_14_ITEM7_P49_S2	The increase in shipments was primarily due to modest improvement in market conditions and demand for our products relative to 2012.
764401_14_ITEM7_P49_S3	The decrease in average selling prices was driven by competitive pricing pressures.
764401_14_ITEM7_P49_S4	Sales for both years reflect severely depressed volumes due to the continuation of recessionary conditions in our construction end-markets.
764401_14_ITEM7_P50_S0	Gross profit increased 74.7% to $39.2 million, or 10.8% of net sales, in 2013 from $22.5 million, or 6.2% of net sales, in 2012.
764401_14_ITEM7_P50_S1	The year-over-year increase was primarily due to wider spreads between average selling prices and raw material costs ($15.0 million), higher shipments ($1.5 million) and lower unit conversion costs ($0.8 million).
764401_14_ITEM7_P50_S2	The increase in spreads was driven by lower raw material costs ($31.1 million) and freight expense ($0.2 million) partially offset by lower average selling prices ($16.3 million).
764401_14_ITEM7_P50_S3	Gross profit for both years was unfavorably impacted by depressed shipment volumes and elevated unit conversion costs largely due to reduced operating schedules.
764401_14_ITEM7_P51_S0	SG A expense increased 9.4% to $20.7 million, or 5.7% of net sales, in 2013 from $18.9 million, or 5.2% of net sales, in 2012 primarily due to higher compensation expense ($1.5 million), a reduction in the gain on the settlement of life insurance policies ($460,000) and the relative year-over-year change in the cash surrender value of life insurance policies ($155,000).
764401_14_ITEM7_P51_S1	The increase in compensation expense was primarily driven by higher incentive plan expense due to our improved financial results in 2013.
764401_14_ITEM7_P51_S2	The cash surrender value of life insurance policies increased $555,000 in 2013 compared with $710,000 in 2012 due to the related changes in the value of the underlying investments.
764401_14_ITEM7_P51_S3	These increases in SG A expense were partially offset by lower bad debt expense ($551,000).
764401_14_ITEM7_P52_S0	A gain on the early extinguishment of debt of $425,000 was recorded in 2012 for the discount on our prepayment of the remaining balance outstanding on the subordinated note that was issued in connection with the acquisition of Ivy Steel and Wire, Inc.
764401_14_ITEM7_P52_S1	( Ivy ) in 2011 ( Ivy Acquisition ).
764401_14_ITEM7_P53_S0	Net restructuring charges of $832,000 were recorded in 2012, which included $744,000 for equipment relocation costs and $139,000 for facility closure costs less $11,000 of net proceeds from the sale of decommissioned equipment and a $40,000 adjustment related to the remaining employee separation costs associated with plant closures and other staffing reductions.
764401_14_ITEM7_P54_S0	Other expense for 2013 was $333,000 compared to $188,000 of other income in 2012.
764401_14_ITEM7_P54_S1	The other expense for 2013 was primarily due to the net loss on the disposal of equipment.
764401_14_ITEM7_P55_S0	Interest expense decreased 62.3% to $235,000 in 2013 from $623,000 in 2012 primarily due to the reduction in average debt outstanding during 2013 and the lower interest rate on borrowings on the revolving credit facility relative to the secured subordinated promissory note associated with the Ivy Acquisition that was outstanding in 2012 prior to its prepayment in December 2011.
764401_14_ITEM7_P56_S0	Our effective income tax rate was 34.8% in 2013 compared with 33.6% in 2012 due to changes in permanent book versus tax differences.
764401_14_ITEM7_P57_S0	Net earnings increased to $11.7 million ($0.64 per diluted share) in 2013 from $1.8 million ($0.10 per share) in 2012 primarily due to the increase in gross profit partially offset by higher SG A expense.
764401_14_ITEM7_P58_S0	Operating activities provided $29.2 million of cash in 2014 primarily from net earnings adjusted for non-cash items and a reduction in the net working capital components of accounts receivable, inventories, and accounts payable and accrued expenses.
764401_14_ITEM7_P58_S1	Net working capital provided $2.4 million of cash due to a $21.3 million increase in accounts payable and accrued expenses partially offset by a $16.8 million increase in inventories and a $2.1 million increase in accounts receivable.
764401_14_ITEM7_P58_S2	The increases in accounts payable and accrued expenses and inventories were largely related to higher raw material purchases driven by the increase in sales.
764401_14_ITEM7_P58_S3	The increase in accounts receivable was primarily due to the increase in sales.
764401_14_ITEM7_P59_S0	Operating activities provided $36.8 million of cash in 2013 primarily from net earnings adjusted for non-cash items and a reduction in net working capital.
764401_14_ITEM7_P59_S1	Net working capital provided $9.7 million of cash due to a $7.0 million decrease in inventories, a $1.7 million increase in accounts payable and accrued expenses, and a $1.0 million decrease in accounts receivable.
764401_14_ITEM7_P59_S2	The decrease in inventories was primarily due to lower raw material purchases and unit costs.
764401_14_ITEM7_P59_S3	The increase in accounts payable and accrued expenses was largely related to changes in the mix of vendor payments and terms.
764401_14_ITEM7_P59_S4	The decrease in accounts receivable was primarily driven by a reduction in days sales outstanding.
764401_14_ITEM7_P60_S0	Operating activities provided $13.1 million of cash in 2012 primarily from net earnings adjusted for non-cash items and a reduction in net working capital.
764401_14_ITEM7_P60_S1	Net working capital provided $0.9 million of cash as a $10.6 million decrease in inventories was partially offset by a $9.6 million decrease in accounts payable and accrued expenses, and a $0.2 million increase in accounts receivable.
764401_14_ITEM7_P60_S2	The changes in inventories and accounts payable and accrued expenses were primarily due to lower raw material purchases and unit costs.
764401_14_ITEM7_P61_S0	We may elect to adjust our operating activities depending upon the conditions in our construction end-markets, which could materially impact our cash requirements.
764401_14_ITEM7_P61_S1	While a downturn in the level of construction activity affects sales to our customers, it generally reduces our working capital requirements.
764401_14_ITEM7_P62_S0	Investing activities used $40.4 million of cash in 2014, $6.3 million in 2013 and $8.2 million in 2012.
764401_14_ITEM7_P62_S1	In 2014, $33.9 million of cash was used to fund the ASW Acquisition and $9.0 million for capital expenditures (including $4.5 million to replace property and equipment damaged in the fire at our Gallatin, Tennessee PC strand manufacturing facility), which was partially offset by $2.7 million of insurance proceeds related to the Gallatin fire.
764401_14_ITEM7_P62_S2	In 2013, $5.0 million of cash was used for capital expenditures and $1.9 million for an intangible asset in connection with the acquisition of certain assets from Tatano Wire and Steel, Inc., which was partially offset by $0.6 million of proceeds from life insurance claims.
764401_14_ITEM7_P62_S3	In 2012, $8.1 million of cash was used for capital expenditures.
764401_14_ITEM7_P63_S0	Our investing activities are largely discretionary, providing us with the ability to significantly curtail outlays should future business conditions warrant that such actions be taken.
764401_14_ITEM7_P64_S0	Financing activities used $1.2 million of cash in 2014, $15.1 million in 2013 and $5.0 million in 2012.
764401_14_ITEM7_P64_S1	In 2014, $2.2 million of cash was used for dividend payments, which was partially offset by $1.1 million of proceeds from the exercise of stock options.
764401_14_ITEM7_P64_S2	In 2013, $11.5 million of cash was used to repay debt and $6.6 million for dividend payments (including a special cash dividend of $4.5 million and regular cash dividends totaling $2.1 million), which was partially offset by $3.4 million of proceeds from the exercise of stock options.
764401_14_ITEM7_P64_S3	In 2012, $2.3 million of cash was used to repay debt and $2.1 million for dividends.
764401_14_ITEM7_P65_S0	Our cash is principally concentrated at one financial institution, which at times exceeds federally insured limits.
764401_14_ITEM7_P65_S1	We invest excess cash primarily in money market funds, which are highly liquid securities that bear minimal risk.
764401_14_ITEM7_P66_S0	We have a revolving credit facility (the Credit Facility ) that is used to supplement our operating cash flow and fund our working capital, capital expenditure, general corporate and growth requirements.
764401_14_ITEM7_P66_S1	On February 6, 2012, we entered into an amendment agreement that, among other changes, increased the commitment amount of the Credit Facility from $75.0 million to $100.0 million and extended the maturity date from June 2, 2015 to June 2, 2016.
764401_14_ITEM7_P66_S2	As of September 27, 2014, there were no borrowings outstanding on the Credit Facility, $89.7 million of additional borrowing capacity was available and outstanding letters of credit totaled $1.5 million (see Note 8 to the consolidated financial statements).
764401_14_ITEM7_P66_S3	During 2014, ordinary course borrowings on the Credit Facility were as high as $13.6 million.
764401_14_ITEM7_P66_S4	As of September 28, 2013, there were no borrowings outstanding on the Credit Facility.
764401_14_ITEM7_P67_S0	As part of the consideration for the Ivy Acquisition, we entered into a $13.5 million secured subordinated promissory note (the Note ) payable to Ivy over five years.
764401_14_ITEM7_P67_S1	The Note required semi-annual interest payments in arrears, and annual principal payments payable on November 19 of each year during the period 2011 - 2015.
764401_14_ITEM7_P67_S2	The Note yielded interest on the unpaid principal balance at a fixed rate of 6.0% per annum and was collateralized by certain of the real property and equipment acquired from Ivy.
764401_14_ITEM7_P67_S3	On December 12, 2011, the Company prepaid the remaining balance that was outstanding on the Note for $12.4 million, which represented a discount of $425,000 that was recorded as a gain from the early extinguishment of debt in the 2012 consolidated statement of operations.
764401_14_ITEM7_P68_S0	We believe that, in the absence of significant unanticipated cash demands, cash generated by operating activities will be sufficient to satisfy our expected requirements for working capital, capital expenditures, dividends and share repurchases, if any.
764401_14_ITEM7_P68_S1	We also expect to have access to the amounts available under our Credit Facility.
764401_14_ITEM7_P68_S2	However, should we experience future reductions in our operating cash flows due to weakening conditions in our construction end-markets and reduced demand from our customers, we may need to curtail capital and operating expenditures, delay or restrict share repurchases, cease dividend payments and/or realign our working capital requirements.
764401_14_ITEM7_P69_S0	Should we determine, at any time, that we required additional short-term liquidity, we would evaluate the alternative sources of financing that were potentially available to provide such funding.
764401_14_ITEM7_P69_S1	There can be no assurance that any such financing, if pursued, would be obtained, or if obtained, would be adequate or on terms acceptable to us.
764401_14_ITEM7_P69_S2	However, we believe that our strong balance sheet, flexible capital structure and borrowing capacity available to us under our Credit Facility position us to meet our anticipated liquidity requirements for the foreseeable future.
764401_14_ITEM7_P70_S0	We are subject to inflationary risks arising from fluctuations in the market prices for our primary raw material, hot-rolled steel wire rod, and, to a much lesser extent, freight, energy and other consumables that are used in our manufacturing processes.
764401_14_ITEM7_P70_S1	We have generally been able to adjust our selling prices to pass through increases in these costs or offset them through various cost reduction and productivity improvement initiatives.
764401_14_ITEM7_P70_S2	However, our ability to raise our selling prices depends on market conditions and competitive dynamics, and there may be periods during which we are unable to fully recover increases in our costs.
764401_14_ITEM7_P71_S0	After initially rising in the first half of 2012, wire rod prices declined during the latter part of the year due to reductions in the cost of scrap for wire rod producers and weakening demand.
764401_14_ITEM7_P71_S1	During 2014 and 2013, wire rod prices fluctuated within a narrower range and inflation did not have a material impact on our sales or earnings.
764401_14_ITEM7_P71_S2	Our ability to fully recover increases in wire rod prices over this period has been mitigated by competitive pricing pressures resulting from the reduced level of activity in our construction end-markets.
764401_14_ITEM7_P71_S3	The timing and magnitude of any future increases in the prices for wire rod and the impact on selling prices for our products is uncertain at this time.
764401_14_ITEM7_P72_S0	We do not have any material transactions, arrangements, obligations (including contingent obligations), or other relationships with unconsolidated entities or other persons, as defined by Item 303(a)(4) of Regulation S-K of the SEC, that have or are reasonably likely to have a material current or future impact on our financial condition, results of operations, liquidity, capital expenditures, capital resources or significant components of revenues or expenses.
764401_14_ITEM7_P73_S0	Our contractual obligations and commitments at September 27, 2014 are as follows:
764401_14_ITEM7_P74_S0	(1) Non-cancelable purchase commitments for raw materials.
764401_14_ITEM7_P74_S1	(2) Contractual commitments for capital expenditures.
764401_14_ITEM7_P75_S0	As we look ahead to 2015, we expect continued improvement in the conditions in our construction end-markets following the steep decline in demand that we have experienced in recent years.
764401_14_ITEM7_P75_S1	There are growing indications the recovery in private nonresidential construction, our primary demand driver, is strengthening, which should favorably impact our financial results through higher shipment volumes and operating levels at our facilities.
764401_14_ITEM7_P75_S2	The outlook for infrastructure construction is less clear pending the enactment of a new multi-year federal transportation funding authorization.
764401_14_ITEM7_P76_S0	We continue to focus on the operational fundamentals of our business: closely managing and controlling our expenses; aligning our production schedules with demand in a proactive manner as there are changes in market conditions to minimize our cash operating costs; and pursuing further improvements in the productivity and effectiveness of all of our manufacturing, selling and administrative activities.
764401_14_ITEM7_P76_S1	We expect that our financial results will be favorably impacted by the full-year contribution of the ASW Acquisition together with the realization of additional operating synergies and benefits from the reconfiguration of our welded wire reinforcement operations related to the Ivy Acquisition.
764401_14_ITEM7_P76_S2	Regarding Forward-Looking Statements and Risk Factors ).
764401_14_ITEM7_P76_S3	In addition, we will continue to pursue further acquisitions in our existing businesses that expand our penetration of markets we currently serve or expand our geographic footprint.
764401_14_ITEM7A_P0_S0	Our cash flows and earnings are subject to fluctuations resulting from changes in commodity prices, interest rates and foreign exchange rates.
764401_14_ITEM7A_P0_S1	We manage our exposure to these market risks through internally established policies and procedures and, when deemed appropriate, through the use of derivative financial instruments.
764401_14_ITEM7A_P0_S2	We do not use financial instruments for trading purposes and we are not a party to any leveraged derivatives.
764401_14_ITEM7A_P0_S3	We monitor our underlying market risk exposures on an ongoing basis and believe that we can modify or adapt our hedging strategies as necessary.
764401_14_ITEM7A_P1_S0	We are subject to significant fluctuations in the cost and availability of our primary raw material, hot-rolled steel wire rod, which we purchase from both domestic and foreign suppliers.
764401_14_ITEM7A_P1_S1	We negotiate quantities and pricing for both domestic and foreign wire rod purchases for varying periods (most recently monthly for domestic suppliers), depending upon market conditions, to manage our exposure to price fluctuations and to ensure adequate availability of material consistent with our requirements.
764401_14_ITEM7A_P1_S2	We do not use derivative commodity instruments to hedge our exposure to changes in prices as such instruments are not currently available for wire rod.
764401_14_ITEM7A_P2_S0	Our ability to acquire wire rod from foreign sources on favorable terms is impacted by fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates, foreign taxes, duties, tariffs and other trade actions.
764401_14_ITEM7A_P2_S1	Although changes in wire rod costs and our selling prices may be correlated over extended periods of time, depending upon market conditions and competitive dynamics, there may be periods during which we are unable to fully recover increased wire rod costs through higher selling prices, which would reduce our gross profit and cash flow from operations.
764401_14_ITEM7A_P2_S2	Additionally, should wire rod costs decline, our financial results may be negatively impacted if the selling prices for our products decrease to an even greater degree and to the extent that we are consuming higher cost material from inventory.
764401_14_ITEM7A_P2_S3	Based on our 2014 shipments and average wire rod cost reflected in cost of sales, a 10% increase in the price of steel wire rod would have resulted in a $26.2 million decrease in our annual pre-tax earnings (assuming there was not a corresponding change in our selling prices).
764401_14_ITEM7A_P3_S0	Although we were debt-free as of September 27, 2014, future borrowings under our revolving credit facility are subject to a variable rate of interest and are sensitive to changes in interest rates.
764401_14_ITEM7A_P4_S0	We have not typically hedged foreign currency exposures related to transactions denominated in currencies other than U.S. dollars, as such transactions have not been material historically.
764401_14_ITEM7A_P4_S1	We will occasionally hedge firm commitments for certain equipment purchases that are denominated in foreign currencies.
764401_14_ITEM7A_P4_S2	The decision to hedge any such transactions is made by us on a case-by-case basis.
764401_14_ITEM7A_P4_S3	There were no forward contracts outstanding as of September 27, 2014.
764401_14_ITEM7A_P5_S0	During 2014, a 10% increase or decrease in the value of the U.S. dollar relative to foreign currencies to which we are typically exposed would not have had a material impact on our financial position, results of operations or cash flows.
764401_14_ITEM8_P0_S0	Selected quarterly financial data for 2014 and 2013 is as follows:
764401_14_ITEM8_P1_S0	See accompanying notes to consolidated financial statements.
764401_14_ITEM8_P2_S0	See accompanying notes to consolidated financial statements.
764401_14_ITEM8_P3_S0	See accompanying notes to consolidated financial statements.
764401_14_ITEM8_P4_S0	See accompanying notes to consolidated financial statements.
764401_14_ITEM8_P5_S0	See accompanying notes to consolidated financial statements.
764401_14_ITEM8_P6_S0	Insteel Industries, Inc. ( Insteel or the Company ) is the nation s largest manufacturer of steel wire reinforcing products for concrete construction applications.
764401_14_ITEM8_P6_S1	Insteel is the parent holding company for two wholly-owned subsidiaries, Insteel Wire Products Company ( IWP ), an operating subsidiary, and Intercontinental Metals Corporation, an inactive subsidiary.
764401_14_ITEM8_P7_S0	The Company manufactures and markets prestressed concrete strand ( PC strand ) and welded wire reinforcement, including engineered structural mesh, concrete pipe reinforcement and standard welded wire reinforcement.
764401_14_ITEM8_P7_S1	The Company s products are primarily sold to manufacturers of concrete products and, to a lesser extent, distributors, rebar fabricators and contractors that are located nationwide as well as in Canada, Mexico, and Central and South America.
764401_14_ITEM8_P8_S0	On August 15, 2014, the Company purchased substantially all of the assets associated with the PC strand business of American Spring Wire Corporation ( ASW ) (see Note 4 to the consolidated financial statements).
764401_14_ITEM8_P9_S0	The Company has evaluated all subsequent events that occurred after the balance sheet date through the time of filing this Annual Report on Form 10-K and concluded there were no events or transactions occurring during this period that required additional recognition or disclosure in its financial statements.
764401_14_ITEM8_P10_S0	The Company s fiscal year is the 52 or 53 weeks ending on the Saturday closest to September 30.
764401_14_ITEM8_P10_S1	Fiscal years 2014, 2013 and 2012 were 52-week fiscal years.
764401_14_ITEM8_P10_S2	All references to years relate to fiscal years rather than calendar years.
764401_14_ITEM8_P11_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company and its subsidiaries.
764401_14_ITEM8_P11_S1	All significant intercompany balances and transactions have been eliminated.
764401_14_ITEM8_P12_S0	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States ( U.S. ) requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in the financial statements and accompanying notes.
764401_14_ITEM8_P12_S1	There is no assurance that actual results will not differ from these estimates.
764401_14_ITEM8_P13_S0	The Company considers all highly liquid investments purchased with original maturities of three months or less to be cash equivalents.
764401_14_ITEM8_P14_S0	Concentration of c redit r isk .
764401_14_ITEM8_P15_S0	Financial instruments that subject the Company to concentrations of credit risk consist principally of cash and cash equivalents and trade accounts receivable.
764401_14_ITEM8_P15_S1	The Company s cash is principally concentrated at one financial institution, which at times exceeds federally insured limits.
764401_14_ITEM8_P15_S2	The Company is exposed to credit risk in the event of default by institutions in which its cash and cash equivalents are held and by customers to the extent of the amounts recorded on the balance sheet.
764401_14_ITEM8_P15_S3	The Company invests excess cash primarily in money market funds, which are highly liquid securities.
764401_14_ITEM8_P16_S0	The majority of the Company s accounts receivable are due from customers that are located in the U.S. and the Company generally requires no collateral depending upon the creditworthiness of the account.
764401_14_ITEM8_P16_S1	The Company provides an allowance for doubtful accounts based upon its assessment of the credit risk of specific customers, historical trends and other information.
764401_14_ITEM8_P16_S2	The Company writes off accounts receivable when they become uncollectible.
764401_14_ITEM8_P17_S0	There is no disproportionate concentration of credit risk.
764401_14_ITEM8_P18_S0	The Company accounts for stock-based compensation in accordance with the fair value recognition provisions of Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) Accounting Standards Codification ( ASC ) Topic 718, Compensation Stock Compensation, which requires stock-based compensation expense to be recognized in net earnings based on the fair value of the award on the date of the grant.
764401_14_ITEM8_P19_S0	The Company determines the fair value of stock options issued by using a Monte Carlo valuation model at the grant date, which considers a range of assumptions including the expected term, volatility, dividend yield and risk-free interest rate.
764401_14_ITEM8_P20_S0	The Company recognizes revenue from product sales when products are shipped and risk of loss and title has passed to the customer.
764401_14_ITEM8_P20_S1	Sales taxes collected from customers are recorded on a net basis and are thus excluded from revenue.
764401_14_ITEM8_P21_S0	The Company includes all of the outbound freight, shipping and handling costs associated with the shipment of products to customers in cost of sales.
764401_14_ITEM8_P21_S1	Any amounts paid by customers to the Company for shipping and handling are recorded in net sales on the consolidated statements of operations.
764401_14_ITEM8_P22_S0	Inventories are valued at the lower of weighted average cost (which approximates computation on a first-in, first-out basis) or market (net realizable value or replacement cost).
764401_14_ITEM8_P23_S0	The valuation of inventory includes the costs for material, labor and manufacturing overhead.
764401_14_ITEM8_P24_S0	Property, plant and equipment are recorded at cost or fair market value in the case of the assets acquired through acquisitions, or otherwise at reduced values to the extent there have been asset impairment write-downs.
764401_14_ITEM8_P25_S0	Expenditures for maintenance and repairs are charged directly to expense when incurred, while major improvements are capitalized.
764401_14_ITEM8_P25_S1	Depreciation is computed for financial reporting purposes principally by use of the straight-line method over the following estimated useful lives: machinery and equipment, 3 - 15 years; buildings, 10 - 30 years; land improvements, 5 - 15 years.
764401_14_ITEM8_P25_S2	Depreciation expense was approximately $9.8 million in 2014, $9.7 million in 2013 and $9.8 million in 2012 and reflected in cost of sales and selling, general and administrative expense ( SG A expense ) in the consolidated statements of operations.
764401_14_ITEM8_P26_S0	Capitalized software is amortized over the shorter of the estimated useful life or 5 years and reflected in SG A expense in the consolidated statements of operations.
764401_14_ITEM8_P26_S1	No interest costs were capitalized in 2014, 2013 and 2012.
764401_14_ITEM8_P27_S0	Goodwill is the excess of cost over the fair value of net assets of businesses acquired.
764401_14_ITEM8_P27_S1	Goodwill is not amortized but is tested annually for impairment and whenever events or circumstances change that would make it more likely than not that an impairment may have occurred.
764401_14_ITEM8_P27_S2	The Company performs its annual impairment analysis as of the first day of the fourth quarter each year.
764401_14_ITEM8_P27_S3	The evaluation of impairment involves comparing the current estimated fair value of the reporting unit to its recorded value, including goodwill.
764401_14_ITEM8_P27_S4	The Company will perform a qualitative assessment to determine whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of the reporting unit is less than its carrying amount.
764401_14_ITEM8_P27_S5	It may be necessary to perform a quantitative analysis where a discounted cash flow model is used to determine the current estimated fair value of the reporting unit.
764401_14_ITEM8_P27_S6	Key assumptions used to determine the fair value of the reporting unit as part of the Company s annual testing (and any required interim testing) include: (a) expected cash flow for the five-year period following the testing date; (b) an estimated terminal value using a terminal year growth rate based on the growth prospects of the reporting unit; (c) a discount rate based on the Company s estimated after-tax weighted average cost of capital; and (d) a probability-weighted scenario approach by which varying cash flows are assigned to alternative scenarios based on their likelihood of occurrence.
764401_14_ITEM8_P27_S7	In developing these assumptions, the Company considers historical and anticipated future results, general economic and market conditions, the impact of planned business and operational strategies and all available information at the time the fair value of the reporting unit is estimated.
764401_14_ITEM8_P28_S0	Assumptions in estimating future cash flows are subject to a high degree of judgment and complexity.
764401_14_ITEM8_P28_S1	Changes in assumptions and estimates may affect the fair value of goodwill and could result in impairment charges in future periods.
764401_14_ITEM8_P28_S2	There was no impairment of goodwill in 2014.
764401_14_ITEM8_P29_S0	Other assets consist principally of capitalized financing costs and the cash surrender value of life insurance policies.
764401_14_ITEM8_P29_S1	Capitalized financing costs are amortized using the straight-line method, which approximates the effective interest method over the term of the related credit agreement, and reflected in interest expense in the consolidated statements of operations.
764401_14_ITEM8_P30_S0	Long-lived assets include property, plant and equipment and identifiable intangible assets with definite useful lives.
764401_14_ITEM8_P30_S1	Finite-lived intangible assets are amortized over their estimated useful lives.
764401_14_ITEM8_P30_S2	The Company s intangible assets consist of customer relationships, developed technology and know-how and non-competition agreements that are being amortized on a straight-line basis over their finite useful lives (see Note 7 to the consolidated financial statements).
764401_14_ITEM8_P30_S3	The Company assesses the impairment of long-lived assets whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value may not be fully recoverable.
764401_14_ITEM8_P30_S4	When the Company determines that the carrying value of such assets may not be recoverable, it measures recoverability based on the undiscounted cash flows expected to be generated by the related asset or asset group.
764401_14_ITEM8_P30_S5	If it is determined that an impairment loss has occurred, the loss is recognized in the period in which it is incurred and is calculated as the difference between the carrying value and the present value of estimated future net cash flows or comparable market values.
764401_14_ITEM8_P30_S6	There were no impairment losses in 2014, 2013 and 2012.
764401_14_ITEM8_P31_S0	Fair value of financial instruments .
764401_14_ITEM8_P31_S1	The carrying amounts for cash and cash equivalents, accounts receivable, and accounts payable and accrued expenses approximate fair value because of their short maturities.
764401_14_ITEM8_P32_S0	Income taxes are based on pretax financial accounting income.
764401_14_ITEM8_P33_S0	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the expected tax consequences of temporary differences between the tax bases of assets and liabilities and their reported amounts.
764401_14_ITEM8_P33_S1	The Company assesses the need to establish a valuation allowance against its deferred tax assets to the extent the Company no longer believes it is more likely than not that the tax assets will be fully realized.
764401_14_ITEM8_P34_S0	Basic earnings per share ( EPS ) are computed by dividing earnings available to common shareholders by the weighted average number of shares of common stock outstanding during the period.
764401_14_ITEM8_P34_S1	Diluted EPS are computed by dividing earnings available to common shareholders by the weighted average number of shares of common stock and other dilutive equity securities outstanding during the period.
764401_14_ITEM8_P34_S2	Securities that have the effect of increasing EPS are considered to be antidilutive and are not included in the computation of diluted EPS.
764401_14_ITEM8_P35_S0	In February 2013, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update ( ASU ) No. 2013-02 Reporting of Amounts Reclassified Out of Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income.
764401_14_ITEM8_P35_S1	ASU No. 2013-02 requires an entity to disaggregate the total change of each component of other comprehensive income either on the face of the income statement or as a separate disclosure in the notes.
764401_14_ITEM8_P35_S2	The Company adopted ASU No. 2013-02 in the first quarter of fiscal 2014.
764401_14_ITEM8_P35_S3	The adoption of this update did not have a material effect on the Company s consolidated financial statements.
764401_14_ITEM8_P36_S0	In May 2014, the FASB issued ASU No. 2014-09 Revenue from Contracts with Customers, which will supersede nearly all existing revenue recognition guidance under accounting principles generally accepted in the U.S. ( GAAP ).
764401_14_ITEM8_P36_S1	ASU No. 2014-09 provides that an entity recognize revenue when it transfers promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services.
764401_14_ITEM8_P36_S2	This update also requires additional disclosure about the nature, amount, timing and uncertainty of revenue and cash flows arising from customer contracts, including significant judgments and changes in judgments, and assets recognized from costs incurred to obtain or fulfill a contract.
764401_14_ITEM8_P36_S3	ASU No. 2014-09 allows for either full retrospective or modified retrospective adoption and will become effective for the Company in the first quarter of fiscal 2018.
764401_14_ITEM8_P36_S4	The Company is evaluating the alternative transition methods and the potential effects of the adoption of this update on its consolidated financial statements.
764401_14_ITEM8_P37_S0	On August 15, 2014, the Company purchased substantially all of the assets associated with the PC strand business of ASW for an adjusted purchase price of $33.9 million, subject to certain additional post-closing adjustments (the ASW Acquisition ).
764401_14_ITEM8_P38_S0	ASW manufactured PC strand at facilities located in Houston, Texas and Newnan, Georgia.
764401_14_ITEM8_P38_S1	The Company acquired, among other assets, the accounts receivable and inventories related to ASW s PC strand business, the production equipment at its facility in Houston, Texas and its production equipment and facility in Newnan, Georgia.
764401_14_ITEM8_P38_S2	Pursuant to an agreement with ASW, the Company will lease the Houston facility from ASW with an option to purchase it in the future.
764401_14_ITEM8_P38_S3	In addition, the Company assumed certain of ASW s accounts payable and accrued liabilities related to its PC strand business.
764401_14_ITEM8_P39_S0	Following is a summary of the Company s preliminary allocation of the adjusted purchase price to the fair values of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed as of the date of the ASW Acquisition:
764401_14_ITEM8_P40_S0	In connection with the ASW Acquisition the Company acquired intangible assets consisting of customer relationships, developed technology and know-how and a non-competition agreement.
764401_14_ITEM8_P40_S1	The ASW Acquisition was accounted for as a business purchase pursuant to ASC Topic 805, Business Combinations .
764401_14_ITEM8_P40_S2	Acquisition and integration costs are not included as components of consideration transferred, but are recorded as expenses in the period in which such costs are incurred (See Note 5 to the consolidated financial statements).
764401_14_ITEM8_P41_S0	Following the ASW Acquisition, net sales of the ASW facilities in 2014 were approximately $7.3 million.
764401_14_ITEM8_P41_S1	The actual amount of net sales specifically attributable to the ASW Acquisition, however, cannot be quantified due to the integration actions that were taken by the Company involving the transfer of business between the former ASW facilities and the Company s existing facilities.
764401_14_ITEM8_P41_S2	The Company has determined that the presentation of ASW s earnings for 2014 is impractical due to the integration of ASW s operations into the Company following the ASW Acquisition.
764401_14_ITEM8_P42_S0	The following unaudited supplemental pro forma financial information reflects the combined results of operations of the Company had the ASW Acquisition occurred at the beginning of 2013.
764401_14_ITEM8_P42_S1	The pro forma information reflects certain adjustments related to the ASW Acquisition, including adjusted amortization and depreciation expense based on the fair value of the assets acquired, interest expense related to the borrowings on the Company s revolving credit facility and an appropriate adjustment for the acquisition-related costs in the current year.
764401_14_ITEM8_P42_S2	The pro forma information does not reflect any operating efficiencies or potential cost savings that may result from the ASW Acquisition.
764401_14_ITEM8_P42_S3	Accordingly, this pro forma information is for illustrative purposes and is not intended to represent or be indicative of the actual results of operations of the combined company that may have been achieved had the ASW Acquisition occurred at the beginning of 2013, nor is it intended to represent or be indicative of future results of operations.

764401_14_ITEM8_P44_S0	On November 19, 2010, the Company purchased certain assets and assumed certain liabilities of Ivy Steel and Wire, Inc.
764401_14_ITEM8_P45_S0	Subsequent to the acquisition of Ivy, the Company elected to consolidate certain of its welded wire reinforcement operations in order to reduce its operating costs, which involved the closure of facilities in Wilmington, Delaware and Houston, Texas.
764401_14_ITEM8_P45_S1	These actions were taken in response to the close proximity of Ivy s facilities in Hazleton, Pennsylvania and Houston, Texas to the Company s existing facilities in Wilmington, Delaware and Dayton, Texas.
764401_14_ITEM8_P45_S2	The Houston plant closure was completed in December 2010 and the Wilmington plant closure was completed in May 2011.

764401_14_ITEM8_P49_S0	Fair value is defined as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date.
764401_14_ITEM8_P49_S1	The authoritative guidance for fair value measurements establishes a three-level fair value hierarchy that encourages an entity to maximize the use of observable inputs and minimize the use of unobservable inputs when measuring fair value.
764401_14_ITEM8_P49_S2	The three levels of inputs used to measure fair value are as follows:
764401_14_ITEM8_P50_S0	Level 1 - Quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.
764401_14_ITEM8_P51_S0	Level 2 - Observable inputs other than quoted prices included in Level 1, such as quoted prices for similar assets and liabilities in active markets.
764401_14_ITEM8_P52_S0	Level 3 - Unobservable inputs that are supported by little or no market activity and that are significant to the fair value of the assets or liabilities, including certain pricing models, discounted cash flow methodologies and similar techniques that use significant unobservable inputs.
764401_14_ITEM8_P53_S0	As of September 27, 2014 and September 28, 2013, the Company held financial assets that are required to be measured at fair value on a recurring basis.
764401_14_ITEM8_P53_S1	The financial assets held by the Company and the fair value hierarchy used to determine their fair values are as follows:
764401_14_ITEM8_P54_S0	Cash equivalents, which include all highly liquid investments with original maturities of three months or less, are classified as Level 1 of the fair value hierarchy.
764401_14_ITEM8_P54_S1	The carrying amount of the Company s cash equivalents, which consist of investments in money market funds, approximates fair value due to their short maturities.
764401_14_ITEM8_P54_S2	Cash surrender value of life insurance policies are classified as Level 2.
764401_14_ITEM8_P54_S3	The fair value of the life insurance policies was determined by the underwriting insurance company s valuation models and represents the guaranteed value the Company would receive upon surrender of these policies as of the reporting date.
764401_14_ITEM8_P55_S0	As of September 27, 2014 and September 28, 2013, the Company had no nonfinancial assets that are required to be measured at fair value on a nonrecurring basis other than the assets and liabilities that were acquired from ASW at fair value (see Note 4 to the consolidated financial statements).
764401_14_ITEM8_P55_S1	The carrying amounts of accounts receivable, accounts payable and accrued expenses approximates fair value due to the short-term maturities of these financial instruments.
764401_14_ITEM8_P56_S0	The primary components of the Company s intangible assets and the related accumulated amortization are as follows:
764401_14_ITEM8_P57_S0	Amortization expense for intangibles was $438,000 in 2014, $163,000 in 2013 and $0 in 2012.
764401_14_ITEM8_P57_S1	Amortization expense for the next five years, assuming no change in estimated useful lives of identified intangible assets, is $866,000 in 2015, $866,000 in 2016, $861,000 in 2017, $629,000 in 2018 and $414,000 in 2019.
764401_14_ITEM8_P58_S0	The Company has a revolving credit facility (the Credit Facility ) that is used to supplement its operating cash flow and fund its working capital, capital expenditure, general corporate and growth requirements.
764401_14_ITEM8_P58_S1	On February 6, 2012, the Company and each of its wholly-owned subsidiaries entered into an amendment agreement that, among other changes, increased the commitment amount of the Credit Facility from $75.0 million to $100.0 million and extended the maturity date from June 2, 2015 to June 2, 2016.
764401_14_ITEM8_P59_S0	Advances under the Credit Facility are limited to the lesser of the revolving loan commitment amount (currently $100.0 million) or a borrowing base amount that is calculated based upon a percentage of eligible receivables and inventories.
764401_14_ITEM8_P59_S1	As of September 27, 2014, no borrowings were outstanding on the Credit Facility, $89.7 million of borrowing capacity was available and outstanding letters of credit totaled $1.5 million.
764401_14_ITEM8_P59_S2	As of September 28, 2013, no borrowings were outstanding on the Credit Facility.
764401_14_ITEM8_P60_S0	Interest rates on the Credit Facility are based upon (1) an index rate that is established at the highest of the prime rate, 0.50% plus the federal funds rate or the LIBOR rate plus the excess of the then-applicable margin for LIBOR loans over the then-applicable margin for index rate loans, or (2) at the election of the Company, a LIBOR rate, plus in either case, an applicable interest rate margin.
764401_14_ITEM8_P60_S1	The applicable interest rate margins are adjusted on a quarterly basis based upon the amount of excess availability on the Credit Facility within the range of 0.50% - 1.25% for index rate loans and 1.50% - 2.50% for LIBOR loans.
764401_14_ITEM8_P60_S2	In addition, the applicable interest rate margins would be increased by 2.00% upon the occurrence of certain events of default provided for under the terms of the Credit Facility.
764401_14_ITEM8_P60_S3	Based on the Company s excess availability as of September 27, 2014, the applicable interest rate margins on the Credit Facility were 0.50% for index rate loans and 1.50% for LIBOR loans.
764401_14_ITEM8_P61_S0	The Company s ability to borrow available amounts under the Credit Facility will be restricted or eliminated in the event of certain covenant breaches, events of default or if the Company is unable to make certain representations and warranties provided for under the terms of the Credit Facility.
764401_14_ITEM8_P61_S1	The Company is required to maintain a fixed charge coverage ratio of not less than 1.10 at the end of each fiscal quarter for the twelve-month period then ended when the amount of liquidity on the Credit Facility is less than $13.5 million.
764401_14_ITEM8_P61_S2	In addition, the terms of the Credit Facility restrict the Company s ability to, among other things: engage in certain business combinations or divestitures; make investments in or loans to third parties, unless certain conditions are met with respect to such investments or loans; pay cash dividends or repurchase shares of the Company s stock subject to certain minimum borrowing availability requirements; incur or assume indebtedness; issue securities; enter into certain transactions with affiliates of the Company; or permit liens to encumber the Company s property and assets.
764401_14_ITEM8_P61_S3	The terms of the Credit Facility also provide that an event of default will occur with respect to the Company upon the occurrence of, among other things: defaults or breaches under the loan documents, subject in certain cases to cure periods; defaults or breaches by the Company or any of its subsidiaries under any agreement resulting in the acceleration of amounts above certain thresholds or payment defaults above certain thresholds; certain events of bankruptcy or insolvency with respect to the Company; certain entries of judgment against the Company or any of its subsidiaries, which are not covered by insurance; or a change of control of the Company.
764401_14_ITEM8_P61_S4	As of September 27, 2014, the Company was in compliance with all of the financial and negative covenants under the Credit Facility and there have not been any events of default.
764401_14_ITEM8_P62_S0	Amortization of capitalized financing costs associated with the credit facility was $102,000 in 2014, $102,000 in 2013 and $97,000 in 2012.
764401_14_ITEM8_P62_S1	Accumulated amortization of capitalized financing costs was $4.4 million and $4.3 million as of September 27, 2014 and September 28, 2013, respectively.
764401_14_ITEM8_P62_S2	The Company expects the amortization of capitalized financing costs to approximate the following amounts for the next five fiscal years:
764401_14_ITEM8_P63_S0	As part of the consideration for the acquisition of Ivy, on November 19, 2010 the Company entered into a $13.5 million secured subordinated promissory note (the Note ) payable to Ivy over five years.
764401_14_ITEM8_P63_S1	The Note required semi-annual interest payments in arrears, and annual principal payments payable on November 19 of each year during the period 2011 - 2015.
764401_14_ITEM8_P63_S2	The Note yielded interest on the unpaid principal balance at a fixed rate of 6.0% per annum and was collateralized by certain of the real property and equipment acquired from Ivy.
764401_14_ITEM8_P63_S3	On December 12, 2011, the Company prepaid the remaining balance that was outstanding on the Note for $12.4 million, which represented a discount of $425,000 that was recorded as a gain from the early extinguishment of debt in the consolidated statements of operations in 2012.
764401_14_ITEM8_P64_S0	Under the Company s equity incentive plans, employees and directors may be granted stock options, restricted stock, restricted stock units and performance awards.

764401_14_ITEM8_P65_S0	Under the Company s equity incentive plans, employees and directors may be granted options to purchase shares of common stock at the fair market value on the date of the grant.
764401_14_ITEM8_P65_S1	Options granted under these plans generally vest over three years and expire ten years from the date of the grant.

764401_14_ITEM8_P67_S0	The fair value of each option award granted is estimated on the date of grant using a Monte Carlo valuation model.
764401_14_ITEM8_P67_S1	The weighted-average estimated fair values of stock options granted during 2014, 2013 and 2012 were $7.00, $7.06 and $5.20 per share, respectively, based on the following weighted-average assumptions:
764401_14_ITEM8_P68_S0	The assumptions utilized in the Monte Carlo valuation model are evaluated and revised, as necessary, to reflect market conditions and actual historical experience.
764401_14_ITEM8_P69_S0	The risk-free interest rate for periods within the contractual life of the option was based on the U.S. Treasury yield curve in effect at the time of the grant.
764401_14_ITEM8_P69_S1	The dividend yield was calculated based on the Company s annual dividend as of the option grant date.
764401_14_ITEM8_P69_S2	The expected volatility was derived using a term structure based on historical volatility and the volatility implied by exchange-traded options on the Company s stock.
764401_14_ITEM8_P69_S3	The expected term for options was based on the results of a Monte Carlo simulation model, using the model s estimated fair value as an input to the Black-Scholes-Merton model, and then solving for the expected term.

764401_14_ITEM8_P78_S0	As of September 27, 2014, the Company recorded a current deferred tax asset (net of valuation allowance) of $2.1 million on its consolidated balance sheet in other current assets and a non-current deferred tax liability (net of valuation allowance) of $6.6 million in other liabilities.
764401_14_ITEM8_P78_S1	As of September 28, 2013, the Company recorded a current deferred tax asset (net of valuation allowance) of $2.7 million in other current assets and a non-current deferred tax liability (net of valuation allowance) of $7.3 million in other liabilities.

764401_14_ITEM8_P78_S3	The Company has also recorded deferred tax assets for various state tax credits of $220,000, which will begin to expire in 2015 and principally expire between 2015 and 2020.
764401_14_ITEM8_P79_S0	The realization of the Company s deferred tax assets is entirely dependent upon the Company s ability to generate future taxable income in applicable jurisdictions.
764401_14_ITEM8_P79_S1	GAAP requires that the Company periodically assess the need to establish a valuation allowance against its deferred tax assets to the extent the Company no longer believes it is more likely than not that they will be fully utilized.
764401_14_ITEM8_P79_S2	As of September 27, 2014, the Company had recorded a valuation allowance of $547,000 pertaining to various state NOLs and tax credits that were not expected to be utilized.
764401_14_ITEM8_P79_S3	The valuation allowance established by the Company is subject to periodic review and adjustment based on changes in facts and circumstances and would be reduced should the Company utilize the state net operating loss carryforwards against which an allowance had previously been provided or determine that such utilization is more likely than not.
764401_14_ITEM8_P79_S4	The $183,000 decrease in the valuation allowance during 2014 is primarily due to the expiration of the 2014 tax credits and reduced state income tax rates.
764401_14_ITEM8_P80_S0	As of September 27, 2014, the Company has no material, known tax exposures that require the establishment of contingency reserves for uncertain tax positions.

764401_14_ITEM8_P84_S0	The Company has one defined benefit pension plan, the Insteel Wire Products Company Retirement Income Plan for Hourly Employees, Wilmington, Delaware ( the Delaware Plan ).
764401_14_ITEM8_P84_S1	The Delaware Plan provides benefits for eligible employees based primarily upon years of service and compensation levels.
764401_14_ITEM8_P84_S2	The Company s funding policy is to contribute amounts at least equal to those required by law .
