764401_17_ITEM5_P5_S0	Our August 15, 2014 acquisition of substantially all the assets associated with the PC strand business of American Spring Wire Corporation (the ASW Acquisition ) may materially affect the comparability of the information reflected in the selected financial data presented in this Item 6.
764401_17_ITEM7_P0_S0	The matters discussed in this section include forward-looking statements that are subject to numerous risks.
764401_17_ITEM7_P0_S1	You should carefully read the Cautionary Note Regarding Forward-Looking Statements and Risk Factors in this Form 10-K.
764401_17_ITEM7_P1_S0	O ur operations are entirely focused on the manufacture and marketing of concrete reinforcing products for the concrete construction industry.
764401_17_ITEM7_P1_S1	Our business strategy is focused on: (1) achieving leadership positions in our markets; (2) operating as the lowest cost producer in our industry; and (3) pursuing growth opportunities within our core businesses that further our penetration of the markets we currently serve or expand our footprint.
764401_17_ITEM7_P2_S0	Our consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States ( GAAP ).
764401_17_ITEM7_P2_S1	Our discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations are based on these consolidated financial statements.
764401_17_ITEM7_P2_S2	The preparation of our consolidated financial statements requires the application of these accounting principles in addition to certain estimates and judgments based on current available information, actuarial estimates, historical results and other assumptions believed to be reasonable.
764401_17_ITEM7_P2_S3	Actual results could differ from these estimates.
764401_17_ITEM7_P3_S0	The following critical accounting policies are both important to the depiction of our financial condition and results of operations and require judgments, assumptions and estimates.
764401_17_ITEM7_P4_S0	We recognize revenue from product sales when products are shipped and risk of loss and title has passed to the customer.
764401_17_ITEM7_P4_S1	Sales taxes collected from customers are excluded from revenues and recorded on a net basis.
764401_17_ITEM7_P5_S0	Financial instruments that subject us to concentrations of credit risk consist principally of cash and cash equivalents and trade accounts receivable.
764401_17_ITEM7_P5_S1	Our cash is concentrated primarily at one financial institution, which at times exceeds federally insured limits.
764401_17_ITEM7_P5_S2	We are exposed to credit risk in the event of default by institutions in which our cash and cash equivalents are held and by customers to the extent of the amounts recorded on the balance sheet.
764401_17_ITEM7_P6_S0	We invest excess cash primarily in money market funds, which are highly liquid securities that bear minimal risk.
764401_17_ITEM7_P7_S0	Most of our accounts receivable are due from customers that are located in the U.S. and are generally not secured by collateral depending upon the creditworthiness of the account.
764401_17_ITEM7_P7_S1	We provide an allowance for doubtful accounts based upon our assessment of the credit risk of specific customers, historical trends and other information.
764401_17_ITEM7_P8_S0	There is no disproportionate concentration of credit risk.
764401_17_ITEM7_P9_S0	We maintain allowances for doubtful accounts for estimated losses resulting from the potential inability of our customers to make required payments on outstanding balances owed to us.
764401_17_ITEM7_P9_S1	Significant management judgments and estimates are used in establishing the allowances.
764401_17_ITEM7_P9_S2	These judgments and estimates consider such factors as the financial position, cash flows and payment history of our customers as well as current and expected business conditions.
764401_17_ITEM7_P9_S3	It is reasonably likely that actual collections will differ from our estimates, which may result in increases or decreases in the allowances.
764401_17_ITEM7_P9_S4	Adjustments to the allowances may also be required if there are significant changes in the financial condition of our customers.
764401_17_ITEM7_P10_S0	We periodically evaluate the carrying value of our inventory.
764401_17_ITEM7_P10_S1	This evaluation includes assessing the adequacy of allowances for losses in the normal course of operations, providing for excess and obsolete inventory, and ensuring that inventory is valued at the lower of cost or estimated net realizable value.
764401_17_ITEM7_P10_S2	Our evaluation considers such factors as the cost of inventory, future demand, our historical experience and market conditions.
764401_17_ITEM7_P10_S3	In assessing the realization of inventory values, we are required to make judgments and estimates regarding future market conditions.
764401_17_ITEM7_P10_S4	Because of the subjective nature of these judgments and estimates, it is reasonably likely that actual outcomes will differ from our estimates.
764401_17_ITEM7_P10_S5	Adjustments to these reserves may be required if actual market conditions are substantially different than the assumptions underlying our estimates.
764401_17_ITEM7_P11_S0	We review long-lived assets, which consist principally of property, plant and equipment and finite-lived intangibles, for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value of the asset may not be fully recoverable.
764401_17_ITEM7_P11_S1	Recoverability of long-lived assets to be held and used is measured based on the future net undiscounted cash flows expected to be generated by the related asset or asset group.
764401_17_ITEM7_P11_S2	If it is determined that an impairment loss has been incurred, the impairment loss is recognized in the period in which it is incurred and is calculated based on the difference between the carrying value and the present value of estimated future net cash flows or comparable market values.
764401_17_ITEM7_P12_S0	Assets to be disposed of by sale are recorded at the lower of carrying value or fair value less selling cost when we have committed to a disposal plan, and are reported separately as assets held for sale on our balance sheet.
764401_17_ITEM7_P13_S0	Unforeseen events and changes in circumstances and market conditions could negatively affect the value of assets and result in an impairment charge.
764401_17_ITEM7_P14_S0	Goodwill is tested annually for impairment and whenever events or circumstances change that would make it more likely than not that an impairment may have occurred.
764401_17_ITEM7_P14_S1	We perform our annual impairment analysis as of the first day of the fourth quarter each fiscal year, which involves comparing the current estimated fair value of the reporting unit to its recorded value, including goodwill.
764401_17_ITEM7_P15_S0	We perform a qualitative assessment to determine whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of the reporting unit is less than its carrying amount.
764401_17_ITEM7_P15_S1	It may be necessary to perform a quantitative analysis where a discounted cash flow model is used to determine the current estimated fair value of the reporting unit.
764401_17_ITEM7_P15_S2	Key assumptions used to determine the fair value of the reporting unit as part of our annual testing (and any required interim testing) include: (a) expected cash flows for the five-year period following the testing date; (b) an estimated terminal value using a terminal year growth rate based on the growth prospects of the reporting unit; (c) a discount rate based on our estimated after-tax weighted average cost of capital; and (d) a probability-weighted scenario approach by which varying cash flows are assigned to alternative scenarios based on their likelihood of occurrence.
764401_17_ITEM7_P15_S3	In developing these assumptions, we consider historical and anticipated future results, general economic and market conditions, the impact of planned business and operational strategies and all available information at the time the fair value of the reporting unit is estimated.
764401_17_ITEM7_P16_S0	W e monitor our operating results throughout the year to determine if events or changes in circumstances warrant any interim impairment testing.
764401_17_ITEM7_P16_S1	Otherwise, goodwill will be subject to the required annual impairment test during our fourth quarter.
764401_17_ITEM7_P16_S2	Changes in the judgments and estimates underlying our analysis of goodwill for possible impairment, including the expected future operating cash flows and discount rate, could reduce our estimated fair value in the future and result in an impairment of goodwill.
764401_17_ITEM7_P16_S3	There was no goodwill impairment loss recognized in fiscal 2017.
764401_17_ITEM7_P17_S0	We are self-insured for certain losses relating to medical and workers compensation claims.
764401_17_ITEM7_P17_S1	Self-insurance claims filed and claims incurred but not reported are accrued based upon our estimates of the discounted ultimate cost for uninsured claims incurred using actuarial assumptions followed by the insurance industry and historical experience.
764401_17_ITEM7_P17_S2	These estimates are subject to a high degree of variability based upon future inflation rates, litigation trends, changes in benefit levels and claim settlement patterns.
764401_17_ITEM7_P17_S3	Because of uncertainties related to these factors as well as the possibility of changes in the underlying facts and circumstances, future adjustments to these reserves may be required.
764401_17_ITEM7_P18_S0	We are involved in claims, lawsuits and other proceedings, which arise in the ordinary course of business.
764401_17_ITEM7_P18_S1	The eventual outcome of such matters and the potential losses that we may ultimately incur are subject to a high degree of uncertainty.
764401_17_ITEM7_P19_S0	We record expenses for litigation when it is probable that a liability has been incurred and the amount of the loss can be reasonably estimated.
764401_17_ITEM7_P19_S1	We estimate the probability of such losses based on the advice of legal counsel, the outcome of similar litigation, the status of the lawsuits and other factors.
764401_17_ITEM7_P19_S2	Due to the numerous factors that enter into these judgments and assumptions, it is reasonably likely that actual outcomes will differ from our estimates.
764401_17_ITEM7_P19_S3	We monitor our potential exposure to these contingencies on a regular basis and may adjust our estimates as additional information becomes available or as there are significant developments.
764401_17_ITEM7_P20_S0	We account for stock-based compensation arrangements, including stock option grants and restricted stock units, in accordance with the provisions of ASC Topic 718, Compensation - Stock Compensation.
764401_17_ITEM7_P20_S1	Under these provisions, compensation cost is recognized based on the fair value of equity awards on the date of grant and amortized on a straight-line basis over the vesting period.
764401_17_ITEM7_P21_S0	We use the Monte Carlo valuation model to determine the fair value of stock options at the date of grant, which requires us to make assumptions for the expected term, volatility, dividend yield, risk-free interest rate and forfeiture rates.
764401_17_ITEM7_P21_S1	These assumptions are based on historical information and judgment regarding market factors and trends.
764401_17_ITEM7_P21_S2	If actual results differ from our assumptions and judgments used in estimating these factors, future adjustments to these estimates may be required.
764401_17_ITEM7_P22_S0	Assumptions for employee benefit plan .
764401_17_ITEM7_P23_S0	We account for our supplemental employee retirement plans (each, a SERP ) in accordance with ASC Topic 715, Compensation - Retirement Benefits.
764401_17_ITEM7_P24_S0	Under the provisions of ASC Topic 715, we recognize net periodic pension cost and value liabilities based on certain actuarial assumptions, principally the assumed discount rate.
764401_17_ITEM7_P25_S0	The discount rate we utilize for determining net periodic pension cost and the related benefit obligation for the SERPs is based, in part, on current interest rates earned on long-term bonds that receive one of the two highest ratings assigned by recognized rating agencies.
764401_17_ITEM7_P25_S1	Our discount rate assumptions are adjusted as of each valuation date to reflect current interest rates on such long-term bonds.
764401_17_ITEM7_P25_S2	The discount rate is used to determine the actuarial present value of the benefit obligations as of the valuation date as well as the interest component of the net periodic pension cost for the following year.
764401_17_ITEM7_P25_S3	The discount rate for the SERPs was 3.75% for fiscal years 2017 and 2016 and 4.25% for fiscal 2015.
764401_17_ITEM7_P26_S0	The a ssumed discount rate is reevaluated annually.
764401_17_ITEM7_P26_S1	Changes in this assumption can result in the recognition of a materially different pension cost over different periods and a materially different liability amount in our consolidated financial statements.
764401_17_ITEM7_P26_S2	A reduction in the assumed discount rate generally results in an actuarial loss, as the actuarially-determined present value of estimated future benefit payments will increase.
764401_17_ITEM7_P26_S3	Conversely, an increase in the assumed discount rate generally results in an actuarial gain.
764401_17_ITEM7_P26_S4	However, any actuarial gains generated in future periods reduce the negative amortization effect of any cumulative unamortized actuarial losses, while any actuarial losses generated in future periods reduce the favorable amortization effect of any cumulative unamortized actuarial gains.
764401_17_ITEM7_P27_S0	The projected benefit obligations and net periodic pension cost for the SERPs are based in part on expected increases in future compensation levels.
764401_17_ITEM7_P27_S1	Our assumption for the expected increase in future compensation levels is based upon our average historical experience and our intentions regarding future compensation increases, which generally approximates average long-term inflation rates.
764401_17_ITEM7_P28_S0	We currently expect net periodic pension cost for fiscal 2018 to be $806,000 for the SERPs.
764401_17_ITEM7_P28_S1	Cash contributions to the SERPs during fiscal 2018 are expected to be $358,000.
764401_17_ITEM7_P29_S0	A 0.25% decrease in the assumed discount rate for our SERPs would have increased our projected and accumulated benefit obligations as of September 30, 2017 by approximately $284,000 and $230,000, respectively, and our expected net periodic pension cost for fiscal 2018 by approximately $31,000.
764401_17_ITEM7_P30_S0	See Note 10 to our consolidated financial statements for the related accounting and disclosures surrounding our terminated pension plan, the Insteel Wire Products Company Retirement Income Plan for Hourly Employees, Wilmington, Delaware (the Delaware Plan ).
764401_17_ITEM7_P31_S0	The nature and impact of recent accounting pronouncements is discussed in Note 3 to our consolidated financial statements and incorporated herein by reference.
764401_17_ITEM7_P32_S0	Net sales decreased 7.1% to $388.9 million in 2017 from $418.5 million in 201 6 due to lower shipments as average selling prices were essentially unchanged.
764401_17_ITEM7_P32_S1	Shipments in 2017 were unfavorably impacted by adverse weather conditions during the second half of the year including the effect from hurricanes Harvey and Irma on our Texas and Florida facilities together with a reduction in new project activity and competitive pricing pressures.
764401_17_ITEM7_P33_S0	Gross profit decreased 29.8% to $59.8 million, or 15.4% of net sales, in 2017 from $85.2 million, or 20.4% of net sales, in 2016.
764401_17_ITEM7_P33_S1	The year-over-year decrease was primarily due to lower spreads between average selling prices and raw material costs ($16.8 million), the decrease in shipments ($6.4 million) and higher unit conversion costs ($3.4 million).
764401_17_ITEM7_P33_S2	The decrease in spreads was driven by higher raw material costs ($16.2 million) and freight expense ($0.7 million) partially offset by higher average selling prices ($0.1 million).
764401_17_ITEM7_P34_S0	Selling, general and administrative expense ( SG A expense ) decreased 2.2% to $25.5 million, or 6.6% of net sales, in 2017 from $26.1 million, or 6.2% of net sales, in 2016 primarily due to lower compensation expense ($762,000) together with the relative year-over-year change in the cash surrender value of life insurance policies ($332,000) , which was partially offset by higher bad debt ($186,000), travel ($163,000) and employee benefit expense ($160,000).
764401_17_ITEM7_P34_S1	The decrease in compensation expense was largely driven by lower incentive plan expense based on our weaker results in 2017.
764401_17_ITEM7_P34_S2	The cash surrender value of life insurance policies increased $812,000 in 2017 compared with $480,000 in the prior year due to the changes in the value of the underlying investments.
764401_17_ITEM7_P34_S3	The increase in bad debt expense was due to a prior year adjustment to the allowance for doubtful accounts based on our favorable collections experience.
764401_17_ITEM7_P34_S4	The increase in employee benefit costs was primarily due to higher employee supplemental retirement plan expense.
764401_17_ITEM7_P35_S0	A pension plan settlement loss of $2.5 million was incurred in 2016 related to the termination of the Delaware Plan.
764401_17_ITEM7_P36_S0	Net restructuring charges of $164,000 were incurred in 2017 for equipment relocation costs related to the consolidation of our PC strand facilities.
764401_17_ITEM7_P36_S1	Net restructuring charges of $115,000 were incurred in 2016 , which included equipment relocation costs ($186,000), facility closure costs ($89,000) and impairment charges related to the decommissioning of equipment ($20,000) partially offset by a gain on the sale of equipment previously associated with the Newnan, Georgia PC strand facility ($180,000).
764401_17_ITEM7_P37_S0	Our effective income tax rate for 2017 increased slightly to 34.0% from 33.8% in 2016 due to changes in permanent book versus tax differences.
764401_17_ITEM7_P38_S0	Net earnings decreased to $22.5 million ($1.17 per diluted share) in 2017 from $37.2 million ($1.95 per diluted share) in 2016 primarily due to the decrease in gross profit partially offset by lower SG A expense and the pension plan settlement loss incurred in 2016.
764401_17_ITEM7_P39_S0	Net sales decreased 6.5% to $418.5 million in 2016 from $447.5 million in 2015 as a 2.6% increase in shipments was offset by a n 8.8% reduction in average selling prices.
764401_17_ITEM7_P39_S1	Shipments for the prior year benefited from an extra week based on our fiscal calendar.
764401_17_ITEM7_P39_S2	On a pro forma basis adjusting both years to reflect the same 52-week period as 2016, the year-over-year shipment increase was 4.8%.
764401_17_ITEM7_P39_S3	The increase in shipments was primarily due to improved market conditions and increased demand for our products relative to the prior year.
764401_17_ITEM7_P39_S4	The decrease in average selling prices was driven by competitive pricing pressures.
764401_17_ITEM7_P40_S0	Gross profit increased 46.0% to $85.2 million, or 20.4% of net sales, in 2016 from $58.3 million, or 13.0% of net sales, in 2015.
764401_17_ITEM7_P40_S1	The year-over-year increase was primarily due to higher spreads between average selling prices and raw material costs ($22.3 million), lower unit conversion costs ($2.3 million) and the increase in shipments ($1.6 million).
764401_17_ITEM7_P40_S2	The increase in spreads was driven by lower raw material costs ($62.4 million) and freight expense ($0.5 million) partially offset by lower average selling prices ($40.6 million).
764401_17_ITEM7_P41_S0	SG A expense increased 0.9% to $26.1 million, or 6.2% of net sales, in 2016 from $25.8 million, or 5.8% of net sales, in 2015 primarily due to higher compensation expense ($1.8 million), which was partially offset by lower employee benefit ($657,000), bad debt ($250,000) and legal expense ($114,000) together with the relative year-over-year change in the cash surrender value of life insurance policies ($441,000).
764401_17_ITEM7_P41_S1	The increase in compensation expense was largely driven by higher incentive plan expense due to our improved financial results in 2016.
764401_17_ITEM7_P41_S2	The decrease in employee benefit costs was primarily related to a reduction in high-dollar health insurance claims.
764401_17_ITEM7_P41_S3	The decrease in bad debt expense was due to an adjustment to the allowance for doubtful accounts based on our favorable collections experience.
764401_17_ITEM7_P41_S4	The cash surrender value of life insurance policies increased $480,000 in 2016 compared with $39,000 in 2015 due to the changes in the value of the underlying investments.
764401_17_ITEM7_P42_S0	A pension plan settlement loss of $2.5 million was incurred in 2016 related to the termination of the Delaware Plan.
764401_17_ITEM7_P43_S0	Net restructuring charges of $115,000 were incurred in 2016 related to the consolidation of our PC strand facilities, including equipment relocation costs ($186,000), facility closure costs ($89,000) and impairment charges related to the decommissioning of equipment ($20,000) partially offset by a gain on the sale of equipment previously associated with the Newnan, Georgia PC strand facility ($180,000).
764401_17_ITEM7_P43_S1	Net restructuring charges of $349,000 were incurred in 2015 related to the closure of the Newnan facility, which included facility closure costs ($547,000), impairment charges related to the decommissioning of equipment ($543,000), equipment relocation costs ($79,000) and employee separation costs ($75,000).
764401_17_ITEM7_P43_S2	These charges were partially offset by an $895,000 gain on the sale of the real estate and certain of the equipment associated with the Newnan facility.
764401_17_ITEM7_P44_S0	Other expense for 2016 was $0.2 million compared with other income of $1.1 million in 2015.
764401_17_ITEM7_P44_S1	The other income for 2015 was primarily related to a $1.7 million net gain from insurance proceeds attributable to the replacement of property and equipment damaged in the fire at our Gallatin, Tennessee PC strand facility in 2014, partially offset by a $0.7 million charge related to the settlement of a customer dispute.
764401_17_ITEM7_P45_S0	Interest expense decreased 50.6% to $158,000 in 2016 from $320,000 in 2015 primarily due to borrowings on our revolving credit facility during the prior year.
764401_17_ITEM7_P46_S0	Our effective income tax rate for 2016 decreased slightly to 33.8% from 34.1% in 2015 due to changes in permanent book versus tax differences.
764401_17_ITEM7_P47_S0	Net earnings increased to $37.2 million ($1.9 5 per diluted share) in 2016 from $21.7 million ($1.15 per diluted share) in 2015 primarily due to the increase in gross profit partially offset by higher SG A expense and the pension plan settlement loss.
764401_17_ITEM7_P48_S0	Operating activities provided $20.3 million of cash in 2017 primarily from net earnings adjusted for non-cash items partially offset by an increase in the net working capital components of accounts receivable, inventories, and accounts payable and accrued expenses.
764401_17_ITEM7_P48_S1	Net working capital used $15.5 million of cash due to an $11.9 million decrease in accounts payable and accrued expenses and a $10.7 million increase in inventories partially offset by a $7.1 million decrease in accounts receivable.
764401_17_ITEM7_P48_S2	The decrease in accounts payable and accrued expenses was primarily related to lower raw material purchases near the end of the period along with a decrease in accrued salaries, wages and related expenses.
764401_17_ITEM7_P48_S3	The increase in inventories was due to higher raw material costs and, to a lesser extent, quantities on-hand.
764401_17_ITEM7_P48_S4	The decrease in accounts receivable was primarily due to lower sales during the period.
764401_17_ITEM7_P49_S0	Operating activities provided $54.5 million of cash in 2016 primarily from net earnings adjusted for non-cash items and a reduction in the net working capital components of accounts receivable, inventories, and accounts payable and accrued expenses.
764401_17_ITEM7_P49_S1	Net working capital provided $3.2 million of cash due to a $9.0 million increase in accounts payable and accrued expenses partially offset by a $5.2 million increase in inventories and a $0.6 million increase in accounts receivable.
764401_17_ITEM7_P49_S2	The increases in accounts payable and accrued expenses and inventories were largely related to higher raw material purchases near the end of the period.
764401_17_ITEM7_P49_S3	The increase in accounts receivable was primarily due to an increase in days sales outstanding partially offset by lower selling prices.
764401_17_ITEM7_P50_S0	Operating activities provided $35.8 million of cash in 2015 primarily from net earnings adjusted for non-cash items and a reduction in the net working capital components of accounts receivable, inventories, and accounts payable and accrued expenses.
764401_17_ITEM7_P50_S1	Net working capital provided $2.3 million of cash due to a $15.9 million decrease in inventories and a $4.3 million decrease in accounts receivable partially offset by a $17.9 million decrease in accounts payable and accrued expenses.
764401_17_ITEM7_P50_S2	The decrease in inventories and accounts payable and accrued expenses was primarily due to lower raw material purchases and unit costs.
764401_17_ITEM7_P50_S3	The decrease in accounts receivable was related to lower selling prices.
764401_17_ITEM7_P51_S0	We may elect to adjust our operating activities as there are changes in the conditions in our construction end-markets, which could materially impact our cash requirements.
764401_17_ITEM7_P51_S1	While a downturn in the level of construction activity affects sales to our customers, it generally reduces our working capital requirements.
764401_17_ITEM7_P52_S0	Investing activities used $20.9 million of cash in 2017 primarily due to $20.6 million of capital expenditures largely related to the expansion of the Houston, Texas PC strand facility and the addition of a new ESM production line at the St. Joseph, Missouri facility.
764401_17_ITEM7_P52_S1	Investing activities used $13.0 million of cash in 2016 primarily due to capital expenditures largely related to the expansion of the Houston facility.
764401_17_ITEM7_P52_S2	Investing activities used $3.0 million of cash in 2015 primarily related to $7.2 million of capital expenditures and the $1.5 million acquisition of an intangible asset from a competitor, which was partially offset by $3.5 million of proceeds from the sale of the real estate and certain of the equipment associated with the Newnan, Georgia PC Strand facility, $1.7 million of insurance proceeds related to the insurance claim for the fire at our Gallatin, Tennessee PC strand facility in 2014 and $0.5 million of post-closing adjustments associated with the ASW Acquisition.
764401_17_ITEM7_P52_S3	Our investing activities are largely discretionary, providing us with the ability to significantly curtail outlays should future business conditions warrant that such actions be taken.
764401_17_ITEM7_P53_S0	Financing activities used $26.2 million of cash in 2017, $15.9 million in 2016 and $2.5 million in 2015.
764401_17_ITEM7_P53_S1	In 2017, $26.0 million of cash was used for dividend payments (including a special cash dividend of $23.7 million, or $1.25 per share, and regular cash dividends totaling $2.3 million).
764401_17_ITEM7_P53_S2	In 2016, $20.9 million of cash was used for dividend payments (including a special cash dividend of $18.6 million, or $1.00 per share, and regular cash dividends totaling $2.3 million), which was partially offset by $5.1 million of proceeds from the exercise of stock options.
764401_17_ITEM7_P53_S3	In 2015, $2.2 million of cash was used for dividend payments and $0.2 million for financing costs that were incurred in connection with the amendment of our revolving credit facility.
764401_17_ITEM7_P54_S0	Our cash is principally concentrated at one financial institution, which at times exceeds federally insured limits.
764401_17_ITEM7_P54_S1	We invest excess cash primarily in money market funds, which are highly liquid securities that bear minimal risk.
764401_17_ITEM7_P55_S0	We have a $100.0 million revolving credit facility (the Credit Facility ) that is used to supplement our operating cash flow and fund our working capital, capital expenditure, general corporate and growth requirements.
764401_17_ITEM7_P55_S1	In May 2015, we amended the Credit Facility to, among other changes, extend its maturity date from June 2, 2016 to May 13, 2020.
764401_17_ITEM7_P56_S0	Advances under the Credit Facility are limited to the lesser of the revolving loan commitment amount (currently $100.0 million) or a borrowing base amount that is calculated based upon a percentage of eligible receivables and inventories.
764401_17_ITEM7_P56_S1	As of September 30, 2017, no borrowings were outstanding on the Credit Facility, $85.4 million of borrowing capacity was available and outstanding letters of credit totaled $1.8 million (see Note 7 to the consolidated financial statements).
764401_17_ITEM7_P56_S2	As of October 1, 2016, there were no borrowings outstanding on the Credit Facility.
764401_17_ITEM7_P57_S0	We believe that, in the absence of significant unanticipated cash demands, cash and cash equivalents, cash generated by operating activities and the borrowing availability provided under the Credit Facility will be sufficient to satisfy our expected requirements for working capital, capital expenditures, dividends and share repurchases, if any.
764401_17_ITEM7_P57_S1	We also expect to have access to the amounts available under our Credit Facility as required.
764401_17_ITEM7_P57_S2	However, should we experience future reductions in our operating cash flows due to weakening conditions in our construction end-markets and reduced demand from our customers, we may need to curtail capital and operating expenditures, delay or restrict share repurchases, cease dividend payments and/or realign our working capital requirements.
764401_17_ITEM7_P58_S0	Should we determine, at any time, that we require d additional short-term liquidity, we would evaluate the alternative sources of financing that were potentially available to provide such funding.
764401_17_ITEM7_P58_S1	There can be no assurance that any such financing, if pursued, would be obtained, or if obtained, would be adequate or on terms acceptable to us.
764401_17_ITEM7_P58_S2	However, we believe that our strong balance sheet, flexible capital structure and borrowing capacity available to us under our Credit Facility position us to meet our anticipated liquidity requirements for the foreseeable future.
764401_17_ITEM7_P59_S0	We are subject to inflationary risks arising from fluctuations in the market prices for our primary raw material, hot-rolled carbon steel wire rod, and, to a much lesser extent, freight, energy and other consumables that are used in our manufacturing processes.
764401_17_ITEM7_P59_S1	We have generally been able to adjust our selling prices to pass through increases in these costs or offset them through various cost reduction and productivity improvement initiatives.
764401_17_ITEM7_P59_S2	However, our ability to raise our selling prices depends on market conditions and competitive dynamics, and there may be periods during which we are unable to fully recover increases in our costs.
764401_17_ITEM7_P60_S0	During 2017, we were unable to fully recover the escalation in our raw material costs through price increases due to the weakening in demand and competitive pricing pressures.
764401_17_ITEM7_P60_S1	During the second half of 2016, our raw material costs rose over most of the period due to increasing scrap costs for wire rod producers which we were generally able to recover through price increases.
764401_17_ITEM7_P60_S2	During 2015 and through the first half of 2016, wire rod prices declined through most of the period due to reductions in scrap costs which favorably impacted our margins after the higher cost inventory we had purchased in earlier periods was consumed.
764401_17_ITEM7_P60_S3	The timing and magnitude of any future increases in the prices for wire rod and the impact on selling prices for our products is uncertain at this time.
764401_17_ITEM7_P61_S0	We do not have any material transactions, arrangements, obligations (including contingent obligations), or other relationships with unconsolidated entities or other persons, as defined by Item 303(a)(4) of Regulation S-K of the SEC, that have or are reasonably likely to have a material current or future impact on our financial condition, results of operations, liquidity, capital expenditures, capital resources or significant components of revenues or expenses.
764401_17_ITEM7_P62_S0	Our contractual obligations and commitments at September 30, 2017 are as follows:
764401_17_ITEM7_P63_S0	(1) Non-cancelable purchase commitments for raw materials.
764401_17_ITEM7_P64_S0	(2) Contractual commitments for capital expenditures.
764401_17_ITEM7_P65_S0	As we look ahead to 201 8, we expect improved conditions in our construction end-markets.
764401_17_ITEM7_P65_S1	Customer sentiment remains positive and we expect the infrastructure-related portion of our business will be favorably impacted by higher state and local funding in many of our markets.
764401_17_ITEM7_P65_S2	We also expect to benefit from modest increases in nonresidential construction together with the continued recovery of the housing market.
764401_17_ITEM7_P65_S3	We believe the recent compression in spreads that we have experienced will diminish as these factors begin to drive increased demand for our products.
764401_17_ITEM7_P66_S0	We continue to focus on the operational fundamentals of our business: closely managing and controlling our expenses; aligning our production schedules with demand in a proactive manner as there are changes in market conditions to minimize our cash operating costs; and pursuing further improvements in the productivity and effectiveness of all of our manufacturing, selling and administrative activities.
764401_17_ITEM7_P66_S1	We expect that our financial results will be favorably impacted by the realization of additional operating synergies associated with the ASW Acquisition and the related reconfiguration of our PC strand operations as we ramp up the new raw material cleaning and production lines at our Houston plant.
764401_17_ITEM7_P66_S2	As market conditions improve, we also expect gradually increasing contributions from the substantial investments we have made in our facilities in the form of reduced operating costs and additional capacity to support future growth.
764401_17_ITEM7_P66_S3	In addition, we will continue to pursue further acquisitions in our existing businesses that expand our penetration of markets we currently serve or expand our footprint.
764401_17_ITEM7_P67_S0	The statements contained in this section are forward-looking statements.
764401_17_ITEM7_P67_S1	See Cautionary Note Regarding Forward-Looking Statements and Risk Factors .
764401_17_ITEM7A_P0_S0	Our cash flows and earnings are subject to fluctuations resulting from changes in commodity prices, interest rates and foreign exchange rates.
764401_17_ITEM7A_P0_S1	We manage our exposure to these market risks through internally established policies and procedures and, when appropriate, through the use of derivative financial instruments.
764401_17_ITEM7A_P0_S2	We do not use financial instruments for trading purposes and are not a party to any leveraged derivatives.
764401_17_ITEM7A_P0_S3	We monitor our underlying market risk exposures on an ongoing basis and believe we can modify or adapt our hedging strategies as necessary.
764401_17_ITEM7A_P1_S0	W e are subject to significant fluctuations in the cost and availability of our primary raw material, hot-rolled carbon steel wire rod, which we purchase from both domestic and foreign suppliers.
764401_17_ITEM7A_P1_S1	We negotiate quantities and pricing for both domestic and foreign wire rod purchases for varying periods (most recently monthly for domestic suppliers), depending upon market conditions, to manage our exposure to price fluctuations and to ensure adequate availability of material consistent with our requirements.
764401_17_ITEM7A_P1_S2	We do not use derivative commodity instruments to hedge our exposure to changes in prices as such instruments are not currently available for wire rod.
764401_17_ITEM7A_P2_S0	Our ability to acquire wire rod from foreign sources on favorable terms is impacted by fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates, foreign taxes, duties, tariffs and other trade actions.
764401_17_ITEM7A_P2_S1	Although changes in our wire rod costs and selling prices tend to be correlated, in weaker market environments, we may be unable to fully recover increased rod costs through higher selling prices, which would reduce our earnings and cash flows.
764401_17_ITEM7A_P2_S2	Additionally, when raw material costs decline, our financial results may be negatively impacted if the selling prices for our products decrease to an even greater extent and if we are consuming higher cost material from inventory.
764401_17_ITEM7A_P2_S3	Based on our 2017 shipments and average wire rod cost reflected in cost of sales, a 10% increase in the price of wire rod would have resulted in a $21.7 million decrease in our annual pre-tax earnings (assuming there was not a corresponding change in our selling prices).
764401_17_ITEM7A_P3_S0	Although we did not have any balances outstanding on our Credit Facility as of September 30, 2017, future borrowings under the facility are subject to a variable rate of interest and are sensitive to changes in interest rates.
764401_17_ITEM7A_P4_S0	We have not typically hedged foreign currency exposures related to transactions denominated in currencies other than U.S. dollars, as such transactions have not been material historically.
764401_17_ITEM7A_P4_S1	We will occasionally hedge firm commitments for certain equipment purchases that are denominated in foreign currencies.
764401_17_ITEM7A_P4_S2	The decision to hedge any such transactions is made by us on a case-by-case basis.
764401_17_ITEM7A_P4_S3	There were no forward contracts outstanding as of September 30, 2017.
764401_17_ITEM7A_P5_S0	During 2017, a 10% increase or decrease in the value of the U.S. dollar relative to foreign currencies to which we are typically exposed would not have had a material impact on our financial position, results of operations or cash flows.
764401_17_ITEM8_P0_S0	Selected quarterly financial data for 2017 and 2016 is as follows:
764401_17_ITEM8_P1_S0	See accompanying notes to consolidated financial statements.
764401_17_ITEM8_P2_S0	See accompanying notes to consolidated financial statements.
764401_17_ITEM8_P3_S0	See accompanying notes to consolidated financial statements.
764401_17_ITEM8_P4_S0	See accompanying notes to consolidated financial statements.
764401_17_ITEM8_P5_S0	See accompanying notes to consolidated financial statements.
764401_17_ITEM8_P6_S0	Insteel Industries, Inc. ( we, us, our, Insteel or the Company ) is the nation s largest manufacturer of steel wire reinforcing products for concrete construction applications.
764401_17_ITEM8_P6_S1	Insteel is the parent holding company for two wholly-owned subsidiaries, Insteel Wire Products Company ( IWP ), an operating subsidiary, and Intercontinental Metals Corporation, an inactive subsidiary.
764401_17_ITEM8_P7_S0	We manufacture and market prestressed concrete strand ( PC strand ) and welded wire reinforcement ( WWR ), including engineered structural mesh, concrete pipe reinforcement and standard welded wire reinforcement.
764401_17_ITEM8_P7_S1	Our products are primarily sold to manufacturers of concrete products and, to a lesser extent, distributors, rebar fabricators and contractors.
764401_17_ITEM8_P7_S2	We sell our products nationwide across the U.S. and, to a much lesser extent, into Canada, Mexico, and Central and South America.
764401_17_ITEM8_P8_S0	We have evaluated all subsequent events that occurred after the balance sheet date through the time of filing this Annual Report on Form 10-K and concluded there were no events or transactions during this period that required additional recognition or disclosure in our financial statements.
764401_17_ITEM8_P9_S0	Our fiscal year is the 52 or 53 weeks ending on the Saturday closest to September 30.
764401_17_ITEM8_P9_S1	Fiscal years 2017 and 2016 were 52-week periods and fiscal year 2015 was a 53-week period.
764401_17_ITEM8_P9_S2	All references to years relate to fiscal years rather than calendar years.
764401_17_ITEM8_P10_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Insteel and our subsidiaries.
764401_17_ITEM8_P10_S1	All significant intercompany transactions and accounts have been eliminated in consolidation.
764401_17_ITEM8_P11_S0	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States ( U.S. and such accounting principles, GAAP ) requires us to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in the financial statements and accompanying notes.
764401_17_ITEM8_P11_S1	There is no assurance that actual results will not differ from these estimates.
764401_17_ITEM8_P12_S0	We consider all highly liquid investments purchased with original maturities of three months or less to be cash equivalents.
764401_17_ITEM8_P13_S0	Concentration of c redit r isk .
764401_17_ITEM8_P14_S0	Financial instruments that subject us to concentrations of credit risk consist principally of cash and cash equivalents and trade accounts receivable.
764401_17_ITEM8_P14_S1	Our cash is principally concentrated at one financial institution, which at times exceeds federally insured limits.
764401_17_ITEM8_P14_S2	We are exposed to credit risk in the event of default by institutions in which our cash and cash equivalents are held and by customers to the extent of the amounts recorded on the balance sheet.
764401_17_ITEM8_P15_S0	We invest excess cash primarily in money market funds, which are highly liquid securities.
764401_17_ITEM8_P16_S0	The majority of our accounts receivable are due from customers that are located in the U.S. and are generally not secured by collateral depending upon the creditworthiness of the account.
764401_17_ITEM8_P16_S1	We provide an allowance for doubtful accounts based upon our assessment of the credit risk of specific customers, historical trends and other information.
764401_17_ITEM8_P16_S2	We write off accounts receivable when they become uncollectible.
764401_17_ITEM8_P17_S0	There is no disproportionate concentration of credit risk.
764401_17_ITEM8_P18_S0	Stock- b ased c ompensation .
764401_17_ITEM8_P19_S0	We account for stock-based compensation in accordance with the fair value recognition provisions of Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) Accounting Standards Codification ( ASC ) Topic 718, Compensation Stock Compensation, which requires stock-based compensation expense to be recognized in net earnings based on the fair value of the award on the date of the grant.
764401_17_ITEM8_P20_S0	We determine the fair value of stock options issued by using a Monte Carlo valuation model at the grant date, which considers a range of assumptions including the expected term, volatility, dividend yield and risk-free interest rate.
764401_17_ITEM8_P21_S0	We recognize revenue from product sales when products are shipped and risk of loss and title has passed to the customer.
764401_17_ITEM8_P21_S1	Sales taxes collected from customers are excluded from revenues and recorded on a net basis.
764401_17_ITEM8_P22_S0	We include all of the outbound freight, shipping and handling costs associated with the shipment of products to customers in cost of sales.
764401_17_ITEM8_P22_S1	Any amounts paid by customers to us for shipping and handling are recorded in net sales on the consolidated statements of operations.
764401_17_ITEM8_P23_S0	Inventories are valued at the lower of weighted average cost (which approximates computation on a first-in, first-out basis) or market (net realizable value or replacement cost).
764401_17_ITEM8_P24_S0	The valuation of inventory includes the costs for material, labor and manufacturing overhead.
764401_17_ITEM8_P25_S0	Property, plant and equipment are recorded at cost or fair market value in the case of the assets acquired through acquisitions, or otherwise at reduced values to the extent there have been asset impairment write-downs.
764401_17_ITEM8_P26_S0	Expenditures for maintenance and repairs are charged directly to expense when incurred, while major improvements are capitalized.
764401_17_ITEM8_P26_S1	Depreciation is computed for financial reporting purposes principally by use of the straight-line method over the following estimated useful lives: machinery and equipment, 3 - 15 years; buildings, 10 - 30 years; and land improvements, 5 - 15 years.
764401_17_ITEM8_P26_S2	Depreciation expense was approximately $10.5 million in 2017, $10.4 million in 2016 and $10.9 million in 2015 and reflected in cost of sales and selling, general and administrative expense ( SG A expense ) in the consolidated statements of operations.
764401_17_ITEM8_P27_S0	Capitalized software is amortized over the shorter of the estimated useful life or 5 years and reflected in SG A expense in the consolidated statements of operations.
764401_17_ITEM8_P27_S1	No interest costs were capitalized in 2017, 2016 and 2015.
764401_17_ITEM8_P28_S0	Goodwill is the excess of cost over the fair value of net assets of businesses acquired.
764401_17_ITEM8_P28_S1	Goodwill is not amortized but is tested annually for impairment and whenever events or circumstances change that would make it more likely than not that an impairment may have occurred.
764401_17_ITEM8_P28_S2	We perform our annual impairment analysis as of the first day of the fourth quarter each year.
764401_17_ITEM8_P28_S3	The evaluation of impairment involves comparing the current estimated fair value of the reporting unit to its recorded value, including goodwill.
764401_17_ITEM8_P28_S4	We perform a qualitative assessment to determine whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of the reporting unit is less than its carrying amount.
764401_17_ITEM8_P28_S5	It may be necessary to perform a quantitative analysis where a discounted cash flow model is used to determine the current estimated fair value of the reporting unit.
764401_17_ITEM8_P28_S6	Key assumptions used to determine the fair value of the reporting unit as part of our annual testing (and any required interim testing) include: (a) expected cash flows for the five-year period following the testing date; (b) an estimated terminal value using a terminal year growth rate based on the growth prospects of the reporting unit; (c) a discount rate based on our estimated after-tax weighted average cost of capital; and (d) a probability-weighted scenario approach by which varying cash flows are assigned to alternative scenarios based on their likelihood of occurrence.
764401_17_ITEM8_P28_S7	In developing these assumptions, we consider historical and anticipated future results, general economic and market conditions, the impact of planned business and operational strategies and all available information at the time the fair value of the reporting unit is estimated.
764401_17_ITEM8_P29_S0	Assumptions in estimating future cash flows are subject to a high degree of judgment and complexity.
764401_17_ITEM8_P29_S1	Changes in assumptions and estimates may affect the fair value of goodwill and could result in impairment charges in future periods.
764401_17_ITEM8_P29_S2	Based on the results of our impairment analysis, no goodwill impairment losses were recognized in the consolidated statements of operations for 2017 .
764401_17_ITEM8_P29_S3	Subsequent to the analysis, there have been no events or circumstances that indicate any potential impairment of goodwill.
764401_17_ITEM8_P30_S0	Other assets consist principally of capitalized financing costs and the cash surrender value of life insurance policies.
764401_17_ITEM8_P30_S1	Capitalized financing costs are amortized using the straight-line method, which approximates the effective interest method over the term of the related credit agreement, and reflected in interest expense in the consolidated statements of operations.
764401_17_ITEM8_P31_S0	Long-lived assets include property, plant and equipment and identifiable intangible assets with definite useful lives.
764401_17_ITEM8_P31_S1	Finite-lived intangible assets are amortized over their estimated useful lives.
764401_17_ITEM8_P31_S2	Our intangible assets consist of customer relationships, developed technology and know-how and non-competition agreements that are being amortized on a straight-line basis over their finite useful lives (see Note 6 to the consolidated financial statements).
764401_17_ITEM8_P32_S0	We assess the impairment of long-lived assets whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value may not be fully recoverable.
764401_17_ITEM8_P32_S1	When we determine that the carrying value of such assets may not be recoverable, we measure recoverability based on the undiscounted cash flows expected to be generated by the related asset or asset group.
764401_17_ITEM8_P32_S2	If it is determined that an impairment loss has occurred, the loss is recognized in the period in which it is incurred and is calculated as the difference between the carrying value and the present value of estimated future net cash flows or comparable market values.
764401_17_ITEM8_P33_S0	There were no impairment losses in 2017.
764401_17_ITEM8_P33_S1	During 2016 and 2015, we recorded $20,000 and $0.3 million, respectively, of impairment charges related to long-lived assets resulting from the consolidation of our PC strand operations with the closure of the Newnan, Georgia facility (see Note 4 to the consolidated financial statements).
764401_17_ITEM8_P34_S0	Fair value of financial instruments .
764401_17_ITEM8_P34_S1	The carrying amounts for cash and cash equivalents, accounts receivable, and accounts payable and accrued expenses approximate fair value because of their short maturities.
764401_17_ITEM8_P35_S0	Income taxes are based on pretax financial accounting income.
764401_17_ITEM8_P36_S0	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the expected tax consequences of temporary differences between the tax bases of assets and liabilities and their reported amounts.
764401_17_ITEM8_P37_S0	We assess the need to establish a valuation allowance against deferred tax assets to the extent we no longer believe it is more likely than not that the tax assets will be fully realized.
764401_17_ITEM8_P38_S0	Basic earnings per share ( EPS ) are computed by dividing earnings available to common shareholders by the weighted average number of shares of common stock outstanding during the period.
764401_17_ITEM8_P38_S1	Diluted EPS are computed by dividing earnings available to common shareholders by the weighted average number of shares of common stock and other dilutive equity securities outstanding during the period.
764401_17_ITEM8_P38_S2	Securities that have the effect of increasing EPS are considered to be antidilutive and are not included in the computation of diluted EPS.
764401_17_ITEM8_P39_S0	In May 2017, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update ( ASU ) No. 2017-09 Compensation Stock Compensation (Topic 718): Scope of Modification Accounting.
764401_17_ITEM8_P39_S1	ASU No. 2017-09 was issued to clarify and reduce both (i) diversity in practice and (ii) cost and complexity when applying its guidance to changes in the terms and conditions of a share-based payment award.
764401_17_ITEM8_P39_S2	ASU No. 2017-09 will become effective for us in the first quarter of fiscal 2020.
764401_17_ITEM8_P39_S3	We are evaluating the impact that the adoption of this update will have on our consolidated financial statements.
764401_17_ITEM8_P40_S0	In August 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-15 Statement of Cash Flows Topic 230: Classification of Certain Cash Receipts and Cash Payments.
764401_17_ITEM8_P40_S1	ASU No. 2016-15 addresses how certain cash receipts and cash payments are presented and classified in the statement of cash flows with the objective of reducing existing differences in the presentation of these items.
764401_17_ITEM8_P40_S2	The amendments in ASU No. 2016-15 are to be adopted retrospectively and will become effective for us in the first quarter of fiscal 2019.
764401_17_ITEM8_P40_S3	We do not expect the adoption of this update will have a material effect on our consolidated financial statements.
764401_17_ITEM8_P41_S0	In March 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-09 Compensation Stock Compensation Topic 718: Improvements to Employee Share-Based Payment Accounting, which is intended to simplify the accounting for share-based payment transactions, including the income tax consequences, classification of awards as either equity or liabilities and classification on the statement of cash flows.
764401_17_ITEM8_P41_S1	ASU No. 2016-09 will become effective for us in the first quarter of fiscal 2018.
764401_17_ITEM8_P41_S2	We do not expect the adoption of this update will have a material effect on our consolidated financial statements.
764401_17_ITEM8_P42_S0	In February 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-02 Leases, which will replace the guidance in ASC Topic 840.
764401_17_ITEM8_P42_S1	ASU No. 2016-02 was issued to increase transparency and comparability among organizations by recognizing all lease transactions (with terms in excess of 12 months) on the balance sheet as a lease liability and a right-of-use asset.
764401_17_ITEM8_P42_S2	ASU No. 2016-02 will become effective for us in the first quarter of fiscal 2020.
764401_17_ITEM8_P42_S3	We are evaluating the impact that the adoption of this update will have on our consolidated financial statements.
764401_17_ITEM8_P43_S0	In July 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-11 Simplifying the Measurement of Inventory, which requires that an entity measure inventory at the lower of cost and net realizable value.
764401_17_ITEM8_P44_S0	Net realizable value is the estimated selling price in the ordinary course of business less reasonably predictable costs of completion, disposal and transportation.
764401_17_ITEM8_P44_S1	ASU No. 2015-11 will become effective for us in the first quarter of fiscal 2018.
764401_17_ITEM8_P44_S2	We do not expect the adoption of this update will have a material effect on our consolidated financial statements.
764401_17_ITEM8_P45_S0	In May 2014, the FASB issued ASU No. 2014-09 Revenue from Contracts with Customers, which will supersede nearly all existing revenue recognition guidance under GAAP.
764401_17_ITEM8_P45_S1	ASU No. 2014-09 provides that an entity recognize revenue when it transfers promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services.
764401_17_ITEM8_P45_S2	This update also requires additional disclosure about the nature, amount, timing and uncertainty of revenue and cash flows arising from customer contracts, including significant judgments and changes in judgments, and assets recognized from costs incurred to obtain or fulfill a contract.
764401_17_ITEM8_P45_S3	ASU No. 2014-09 allows for either full retrospective or modified retrospective adoption and will become effective for us in the first quarter of fiscal 2019.
764401_17_ITEM8_P45_S4	While we have not yet identified any material changes in the timing of revenue recognition, our evaluation is ongoing and not complete.
764401_17_ITEM8_P46_S0	In 2014 we purchased substantially all of the assets associated with the PC strand business of American Spring Wire Corporation ( ASW Acquisition ).
764401_17_ITEM8_P46_S1	Subsequent to the ASW Acquisition, in 2014, we incurred employee separation costs for staffing reductions associated with the acquisition.
764401_17_ITEM8_P46_S2	In February 2015, we elected to consolidate our PC strand operations with the closure of the Newnan, Georgia facility that had been acquired through the ASW Acquisition, which was completed in March 2015.
764401_17_ITEM8_P47_S0	Following is a summary of the restructuring activities and associated costs that were incurred during 2017, 2016 and 2015:
764401_17_ITEM8_P48_S0	As of October 1, 2016, we recorded restructuring liabilities amounting to $0.3 million on our consolidated balance sheet, including $0.1 million in accounts payable and $0.2 million in accrued expenses.
764401_17_ITEM8_P48_S1	We do not currently expect to incur any additional restructuring charges during 2018 related to the consolidation of our PC strand operations.
764401_17_ITEM8_P49_S0	Fair value is defined as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date.
764401_17_ITEM8_P49_S1	The authoritative guidance for fair value measurements establishes a three-level fair value hierarchy that encourages an entity to maximize the use of observable inputs and minimize the use of unobservable inputs when measuring fair value.
764401_17_ITEM8_P49_S2	The three levels of inputs used to measure fair value are as follows:
764401_17_ITEM8_P50_S0	Level 1 - Quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.
764401_17_ITEM8_P51_S0	Level 2 - Observable inputs other than quoted prices included in Level 1, such as quoted prices for similar assets and liabilities in active markets.
764401_17_ITEM8_P52_S0	Level 3 - Unobservable inputs that are supported by little or no market activity and that are significant to the fair value of the assets or liabilities, including certain pricing models, discounted cash flow methodologies and similar techniques that use significant unobservable inputs.
764401_17_ITEM8_P53_S0	As of September 30, 2017 and October 1, 2016, we held financial assets that are required to be measured at fair value on a recurring basis, which are summarized below:
764401_17_ITEM8_P54_S0	Cash equivalents, which include all highly liquid investments with original maturities of three months or less, are classified as Level 1 of the fair value hierarchy.
764401_17_ITEM8_P54_S1	The carrying amount of our cash equivalents, which consist of investments in money market funds, approximates fair value due to their short maturities.
764401_17_ITEM8_P55_S0	Cash surrender value of life insurance policies are classified as Level 2.
764401_17_ITEM8_P55_S1	The fair value of the life insurance policies was determined by the underwriting insurance company s valuation models and represents the guaranteed value we would receive upon surrender of these policies as of the reporting date.
764401_17_ITEM8_P56_S0	As of September 30, 2017 and October 1, 2016, we had no nonfinancial assets that are required to be measured at fair value on a nonrecurring basis.
764401_17_ITEM8_P56_S1	The carrying amounts of accounts receivable, accounts payable and accrued expenses approximates fair value due to the short-term maturities of these financial instruments.
764401_17_ITEM8_P57_S0	The primary components of our intangible assets and the related accumulated amortization are as follows:
764401_17_ITEM8_P58_S0	Amortization expense for intangibles was $1.2 million in 2017 and 2016 and $1.1 million in 2015.
764401_17_ITEM8_P58_S1	Amortization expense for the next five years, assuming no change in the estimated useful lives of identified intangible assets, is $918,000 in 2018, $705,000 in 2019, $537,000 in 2020 and $414,000 in 2021 and 2022.
764401_17_ITEM8_P59_S0	We have a $100.0 million revolving credit facility (the Credit Facility ) that is used to supplement our operating cash flow and fund our working capital, capital expenditure, general corporate and growth requirements.
764401_17_ITEM8_P59_S1	In May 2015, we amended the Credit Facility to, among other changes, extend its maturity date from June 2, 2016 to May 13, 2020.
764401_17_ITEM8_P60_S0	Advances under the Credit Facility are limited to the lesser of the revolving loan commitment amount (currently $100.0 million) or a borrowing base amount that is calculated based upon a percentage of eligible receivables and inventories.
764401_17_ITEM8_P60_S1	As of September 30, 2017, no borrowings were outstanding on the Credit Facility, $85.4 million of borrowing capacity was available and outstanding letters of credit totaled $1.8 million.
764401_17_ITEM8_P60_S2	As of October 1, 2016, there were no borrowings outstanding on the Credit Facility.
764401_17_ITEM8_P61_S0	Interest rates on the Credit Facility are based upon (1) an index rate that is established at the highest of the prime rate, 0.50% plus the federal funds rate or the LIBOR rate plus the excess of the then-applicable margin for LIBOR loans over the then-applicable margin for index rate loans, or (2) at our election, a LIBOR rate, plus in either case, an applicable interest rate margin.
764401_17_ITEM8_P61_S1	The applicable interest rate margins are adjusted on a quarterly basis based upon the amount of excess availability on the Credit Facility within the range of 0.25% to 0.75% for index rate loans and 1.25% to 1.75% for LIBOR loans.
764401_17_ITEM8_P61_S2	In addition, the applicable interest rate margins would be increased by 2.00% upon the occurrence of certain events of default provided for under the terms of the Credit Facility.
764401_17_ITEM8_P61_S3	Based on our excess availability as of September 30, 2017, the applicable interest rate margins on the Credit Facility were 0.25% for index rate loans and 1.25% for LIBOR loans.
764401_17_ITEM8_P62_S0	Our ability to borrow available amounts under the Credit Facility will be restricted or eliminated in the event of certain covenant breaches, events of default or if we are unable to make certain representations and warranties provided for under the terms of the Credit Facility.
764401_17_ITEM8_P62_S1	We are required to maintain a fixed charge coverage ratio of not less than 1.10 at the end of each fiscal quarter for the twelve-month period then ended when the amount of liquidity on the Credit Facility is less than $12.5 million.
764401_17_ITEM8_P62_S2	In addition, the terms of the Credit Facility restrict our ability to, among other things: engage in certain business combinations or divestitures; make investments in or loans to third parties, unless certain conditions are met with respect to such investments or loans; pay cash dividends or repurchase shares of our stock subject to certain minimum borrowing availability requirements; incur or assume indebtedness; issue securities; enter into certain transactions with our affiliates; or permit liens to encumber our property and assets.
764401_17_ITEM8_P62_S3	The terms of the Credit Facility also provide that an event of default will occur upon the occurrence of, among other things: defaults or breaches under the loan documents, subject in certain cases to cure periods; defaults or breaches by us or any of our subsidiaries under any agreement resulting in the acceleration of amounts above certain thresholds or payment defaults above certain thresholds; certain events of bankruptcy or insolvency; certain entries of judgment against us or any of our subsidiaries, which are not covered by insurance; or a change of control.
764401_17_ITEM8_P62_S4	As of September 30, 2017, we were in compliance with all of the financial and negative covenants under the Credit Facility and there have not been any events of default.
764401_17_ITEM8_P63_S0	Amortization of capitalized financing costs associated with the Credit Facility was $65,000 in 2017 and 2016 and $89,000 in 2015.
764401_17_ITEM8_P63_S1	Accumulated amortization of capitalized financing costs was $4.6 million as of September 30, 2017 and $4.5 million as of October 1, 2016.
764401_17_ITEM8_P63_S2	We expect the amortization of capitalized financing costs to approximate the following amounts for the next five fiscal years:
764401_17_ITEM8_P64_S0	Under our equity incentive plan, employees and directors may be granted stock options, restricted stock, restricted stock units and performance awards.
764401_17_ITEM8_P64_S1	Effective February 17, 2015, our shareholders approved the 2015 Equity Incentive Plan of Insteel Industries, Inc. (the 2015 Plan ), which authorizes up to 900,000 shares of our common stock for future grants under the plan.
764401_17_ITEM8_P64_S2	The 2015 Plan, which expires on February 17, 2025, replaces the 2005 Equity Incentive Plan of Insteel Industries, Inc., which expired on February 15, 2015.
764401_17_ITEM8_P64_S3	As of September 30, 2017, there were 433,000 shares of our common stock available for future grants under the 2015 Plan, which is our only active equity incentive plan.
764401_17_ITEM8_P65_S0	Under our equity incentive plan, employees and directors may be granted options to purchase shares of common stock at the fair market value on the date of the grant.
764401_17_ITEM8_P65_S1	Options granted under the plan generally vest over three years and expire ten years from the date of the grant.
764401_17_ITEM8_P65_S2	Compensation expense associated with stock options is as follows:
764401_17_ITEM8_P66_S0	The remaining unrecognized compensation cost related to unvested options at September 30, 2017 was $330,000, which is expected to be recognized over a weighted average period of 1.49 years.
764401_17_ITEM8_P67_S0	The fair value of each option award granted is estimated on the date of grant using a Monte Carlo valuation model.
764401_17_ITEM8_P67_S1	The weighted-average estimated fair values of stock options granted during 2017, 2016 and 2015 were $11.08, $9.92 and $7.10 per share, respectively, based on the following weighted-average assumptions:
764401_17_ITEM8_P68_S0	The assumptions utilized in the Monte Carlo valuation model are evaluated and revised, as necessary, to reflect market conditions and actual historical experience.
764401_17_ITEM8_P69_S0	The expected term for options was based on the results of a Monte Carlo simulation model, using the model s estimated fair value as an input to the Black-Scholes-Merton model, and then solving for the expected term.
764401_17_ITEM8_P69_S1	The risk-free interest rate for periods within the contractual life of the option was based on the U.S. Treasury yield curve in effect at the time of the grant.
764401_17_ITEM8_P69_S2	The expected volatility was derived using a term structure based on historical volatility and the volatility implied by exchange-traded options on our stock.
764401_17_ITEM8_P69_S3	The dividend yield was calculated based on our annual dividend as of the option grant date.
764401_17_ITEM8_P70_S0	The following table summarizes stock option activity:
764401_17_ITEM8_P71_S0	Stock option exercises include net exercises for which the optionee received shares of common stock equal to the intrinsic value of the options (fair market value of common stock on the date of exercise less exercise price) reduced by any applicable withholding taxes.
764401_17_ITEM8_P72_S0	Restricted stock units ( RSUs ) granted under our equity incentive plan are valued based upon the fair market value on the date of the grant and provide for a dividend equivalent payment which is included in compensation expense.
764401_17_ITEM8_P72_S1	The vesting period for RSUs is generally one year from the date of grant for RSUs granted to directors and three years from the date of the grant for RSUs granted to employees.
764401_17_ITEM8_P72_S2	RSUs do not have voting rights.

764401_17_ITEM8_P76_S0	The reconciliation between income taxes computed at the federal statutory rate and the provision for income taxes is as follows:
764401_17_ITEM8_P77_S0	The components of deferred tax assets and liabilities are as follows:
764401_17_ITEM8_P78_S0	As of September 30, 2017, we recorded a non-current deferred tax liability (net of valuation allowance) of $8.1 million in other liabilities on our consolidated balance sheet.
764401_17_ITEM8_P78_S1	As of October 1, 2016, we recorded a non-current deferred tax liability (net of valuation allowance) of $5.5 million in other liabilities on our consolidated balance sheet.
764401_17_ITEM8_P78_S2	We have $7.4 million of state net operating loss carryforwards ( NOLs ) that begin to expire in 2018, but principally expire between 2018 and 2031.
764401_17_ITEM8_P78_S3	We have also recorded deferred tax assets for various state tax credits of $46,000, which will begin to expire in 2019 and principally expire between 2019 and 2020.
764401_17_ITEM8_P79_S0	The realization of our deferred tax assets is entirely dependent upon our ability to generate future taxable income in applicable jurisdictions.
764401_17_ITEM8_P79_S1	GAAP requires that we periodically assess the need to establish a valuation allowance against our deferred tax assets to the extent we no longer believe it is more likely than not that they will be fully utilized.
764401_17_ITEM8_P79_S2	As of September 30, 2017, we had recorded a valuation allowance of $251,000 pertaining to various state NOLs and tax credits that were not expected to be utilized.
764401_17_ITEM8_P79_S3	The valuation allowance is subject to periodic review and adjustment based on changes in facts and circumstances and would be reduced should we utilize the state net operating loss carryforwards against which an allowance had previously been provided or determine that such utilization is more likely than not.
764401_17_ITEM8_P79_S4	The $29,000 decrease in the valuation allowance during 2017 is primarily due to the reduction in enacted state tax rates and the expiration of state NOLs for which an allowance had been previously recorded.
764401_17_ITEM8_P80_S0	As of September 30, 2017, we had no material, known tax exposures that required the establishment of contingency reserves for uncertain tax positions.
764401_17_ITEM8_P81_S0	We classify interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits as part of income tax expense.
764401_17_ITEM8_P81_S1	There were no interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits incurred during 2017, 2016 and 2015.
764401_17_ITEM8_P82_S0	We file U.S. federal income tax returns as well as state and local income tax returns in various jurisdictions.
764401_17_ITEM8_P82_S1	Federal and various state tax returns filed subsequent to 2012 remain subject to examination.
764401_17_ITEM8_P83_S0	We had one defined benefit pension plan, the Insteel Wire Products Company Retirement Income Plan for Hourly Employees, Wilmington, Delaware (the Delaware Plan ).
764401_17_ITEM8_P83_S1	The Delaware Plan provided benefits for eligible employees based primarily upon years of service and compensation levels.
764401_17_ITEM8_P83_S2	The Delaware Plan was frozen effective September 30, 2008 whereby participants no longer earned additional benefits.
764401_17_ITEM8_P84_S0	During 2016, we terminated the Delaware Plan and settled plan liabilities through either lump sum distributions to plan participants or annuity contracts purchased from a third-party insurance company that provided for the payment of vested benefits to those participants that did not elect the lump sum option.
764401_17_ITEM8_P84_S1	As of October 1, 2016, there were no remaining plan assets.
764401_17_ITEM8_P84_S2	We made contributions totaling $1.9 million and $234,000 to the Delaware Plan during 2016 and 2015, respectively.
764401_17_ITEM8_P85_S0	As a result of the pension termination, unrecognized losses, which previously were recorded in accumulated other comprehensive loss on our consolidated balance sheets, were recognized as expense and the pension plan settlement loss of $2.5 million was recorded on our consolidated statements of operations for the year ended October 1, 2016.

764401_17_ITEM8_P87_S0	Net periodic pension cost for the Delaware Plan includes the following components:
764401_17_ITEM8_P88_S0	The assumptions used in the valuation of the Delaware Plan are as follows:
764401_17_ITEM8_P89_S0	The assumed discount rate is established as of our fiscal year-end measurement date.
764401_17_ITEM8_P90_S0	In establishing the discount rate, we reviewed published market indices of high-quality debt securities, adjusted as appropriate for duration, and high-quality bond yield curves applicable to the expected benefit payments of the Delaware Plan.
764401_17_ITEM8_P90_S1	To develop the expected long-term rate of return on assets assumption, we considered the historical returns and future expectations of returns for each asset class, as well as the target asset allocation of the Delaware Plan portfolio.
764401_17_ITEM8_P91_S0	Prior to the termination and settlement of the Delaware Plan the fundamental goal underlying the investment policy was to ensure that its assets were invested in a prudent manner to meet its obligations as such obligations became due.
764401_17_ITEM8_P91_S1	The primary investment objectives included providing a total return that would promote the goal of benefit security by attaining an appropriate ratio of plan assets to plan obligations, diversifying investments across and within asset classes, minimizing the impact of losses in single investments and adhering to investment practices that complied with applicable laws and regulations.
764401_17_ITEM8_P92_S0	The investment strategy for equities emphasized U.S. large cap equities with the portfolio s performance measured against the S P 500 index or other applicable indices.
764401_17_ITEM8_P92_S1	The investment strategy for fixed income investments was focused on maintaining an overall portfolio with a minimum credit rating of A-1 as well as a minimum rating of any security at the time of purchase of Baa/BBB by Moody s or Standard Poor s, if rated.
764401_17_ITEM8_P93_S0	The Delaware Plan had a long-term target asset mix of 60% equities and 40% fixed income.
764401_17_ITEM8_P93_S1	The asset allocations for the Delaware Plan as of October 3, 2015 were as follows:
764401_17_ITEM8_P94_S0	We have Retirement Security Agreements (each, a SERP ) with certain of our employees (each, a Participant ).
764401_17_ITEM8_P94_S1	Under the SERPs, if the Participant remains in continuous service with us for a period of at least 30 years, we will pay them a supplemental retirement benefit for the 15-year period following their retirement equal to 50% of their highest average annual base salary for five consecutive years in the 10-year period preceding their retirement.
764401_17_ITEM8_P94_S2	If the Participant retires prior to the later of age 65 or the completion of 30 years of continuous service with us, but has completed at least 10 years of continuous service, the amount of their supplemental retirement benefit will be reduced by 1/360th for each month short of 30 years that they were employed by us.
764401_17_ITEM8_P95_S0	In 2005, we revised the SERPs to add Participants and increase benefits to certain existing Participants.
764401_17_ITEM8_P96_S0	The reconciliation of the projected benefit obligation, plan assets, funded status and amounts recognized for the SERPs in our consolidated balance sheets is as follows:

764401_17_ITEM8_P98_S0	The estimated net loss that will be amortized from accumulated other comprehensive loss into net periodic pension cost during 2018 is $150,000.

764401_17_ITEM8_P100_S0	The assumed discount rate is established as of our fiscal year-end measurement date.
764401_17_ITEM8_P101_S0	In establishing the discount rate, we review published market indices of high-quality debt securities, adjusted as appropriate for duration, and high-quality bond yield curves applicable to the expected benefit payments of the plan.
764401_17_ITEM8_P102_S0	The SERPs expected rate of increase in compensation levels is based on the anticipated increases in annual compensation.
